post:
Options for watching television in Switzerland   
There are many ways one can receive television programs in Switzerland. Many of the subscription services in Switzerland offer a reasonable range of English-language programming. You can find out the channels offered, availability and pricing information for each of the above services on their official websites.       
All persons capable of receiving television and radio signal in Switzerland are obligated to pay licensing fees to Billag. Yes,   even if you don't watch Swiss TV, and there's not a whole lot you can do about it. It's the law, and you will be served a hefty fine if you don't pay up.       Satellite television reception in Switzerland   
Satellite television is enormously popular with many foreigners living in Switzerland. It is possible to receive these channels for free through Sky or Freesat. The following threads in Englishforum cover most of the details concerning installation* of a satellite dish in Switzerland and what channels you can receive. Sky TV Facts: 
*A few notes about installing satellite dishes in Switzerland: 
Some landlords are against the installation of satellite dishes on their property. There is a federal law that explicitly states that you have the right to receive foreign language television programs (including those broadcast by satellite), but many landlords prohibit the installation of dishes because they destroy the property. 
If you are refused permission to mount a dish on your building, there are a few options.    The above solutions won't prevent the neighbours from complaining that your dish is ugly, but they do save you from getting in trouble over damaging the building.       Importing foreign televisions to Switzerland  
In short: Frequently asked questions about watching foreign programs in Switzerland: There is more information about television reception in Switzerland on  .

post:
Well, after a few days with the GearVR and it's a pretty cool demonstration of the way consumer VR is heading. The main issue is that the resolution isn't good enough and needs to be higher, with a 4k screen as a minimum but ideally 8k would make for unpixellated viewing. I guess that's still a couple/few years away from that though.   
Either way it gives a cool effect in the demos and apps that are there and it will only get better as the production/filming techniques improve. I spent Sunday afternoon watching the "Shorts" (short movies, basically) in the Oculus store and they were great (even though they are mostly 2D), I highly recommend going through each and every one in sequence, there are some amazing concepts in them. Very cool.   
I also love the effect of using the "Cinema" setting, it really does feel like you are watching a big screen, albeit heavily pixellated. When the resolution increases it's going to be simply amazing. Same with Netflix, it's just too pixellated to be viable at the moment.   
Consumer VR in general is going to be amazing in a few generations, the possibilities for content are almost endless.

Yes and no. Without going into any great detail:   
Bandwidth costs money in the sense that equipping a neighbourhood with lines, line concentrating devices, and a trunk to the nearest exchange. This "package" will be selected to deliver a certain minimum to each end user, and a certain amount of additional bandwidth to cover customers with greater bandwidth needs, and the whole package with a certain reserve for growth.   
This whole package can handle a certain finite amount of bandwidth, and incurs a specific capital cost.   
It doesn't cost Swisscom any more to deliver you 500 than 20 as long as the package can handle that, they simply "unthrottle" the port your apt is connected on - this is done via software from a central location.   
But when the number of customers with higher speeds starts to increase to the point that they need to install additional kit to cover that demand, then it starts to cost them money. They may need to upgrade devices, or possibly even start pulling new lines. This can get very expensive very quickly.

post: They may have done that in your case but I cancelled with a single phone call.

Just that you do not pay to much: 
There are two Bilag license. On is the radio license which covers radios only and there is a TV license which covers TV only.   
Legally speaking, you will need a radio license when you have a AM/FM or DAB radio. Any radio. In your car, in your phone, in your alarm clock. Also if you have a internet connection at home and you have a device capable of receiving internet radio streams (from anywhere in the world).    
You will need a TV license if and only if (aka iff):   
- You have a TV set which can receive TV (connected to cable socket, connected to a Sat receiver, or has a built in DVB receiver and antenna If you have an old TV with just an analog tuner connected to a DVD player you wont need a TV license).  
- Or you have computer AND a subscription or account with an IP-TV provider (paid or free). An IP-TV provider allows you to watch real live TV stations (from anywhere in the world). Netflix or Amazon Prime are NOT IP-TV providers. Streaming does not need a TV license. A computer alone does not need TV license. (There are also live TV streams where you do not need an account or a subscription. Like the Swiss state TV! If you watch it through their website you do not need a TV license!!)    
As you already in the grips of Billag, select Radio only.     
Also and most importantly, the license is per household and you can have as many devices as you wish. If you live in a shared flat you will only need one license and can share the cost with your flat mate(s).

The short answer would be to read about and understand what additional connection charges apply before you sign a contract.   
And if it turns out that a wire needs to be connected, or a port number determined, then choose one of: 
a) Figure out out yourself and connect the line, or find out the port. 
b) Find someone who already knows and ask nicely. 
c) Pay someone who knows how to do this, an electrician for example.   
I would say you should probably now read up on how you go about returning the Sunrise kit.   
This would still leave you with the problem of whoever you do choose as a provider being able to figure out which two wires are actually connected to the jack in your apartment.   
It might be simpler and cheaper for you if you call Sunrise, ask them to uncancel your line, keep the kit, and find out what the previous tenant's phone number (perhaps by asking the landlord or a neighbour, and explaining why it is that you need this information).   
But if you want to stand on principle and save some money by living without an internet connection, that is your good right.

3. My cablecom TV Mediabox froze up tonight at 21:00.  It said "installation will be complete in 30 mins" and remained blue screen for long time.  Letter in new Horizon box warned that current TV box connection will be disabled "soon".   
4. I have no choice but to install new Horizon box because Cablecom hotline at 21:00 on a Good Friday is dead. Just music.   
5. I installed the Horizon box, smooth installation. HD TV all works etc.   
Now comes the surprise. Internet and telephone on the Horizon box does not connect.   
I have to replug in my current cable modem (with internet and telephone) back into another socket in the wall.   
I guess I have to wait til the cablecom company activates my internet and telephone on my new Horizon box.  When? 
Seeing it is Easter weekend, I am expecting more cock-ups.       
PS: GUI sucks. Missing many direct buttons on controller and navigating thru the Menu is painful, almost like the old Handphone internet version 1.0. (I cannot even remember the name of this service).   
However, the box is surely faster and more responsive. New Hardware. By Samsung.    
PPS: I am not complaining because I know such things can cock up.  Just wanted to share the experience.
My husband is happy with Xiaomi. Unfortuantely I don't know the model as it does not write on the phone, but should be around 200fr online.

Oh really? Try this category, you might need to have some patience, but there are really very good deals that can be had there.          Warranty is overrated. Computers are quite reliable these days. If it worked fine already for two years, chances are it'll last much longer. For a brand new laptop you do need the warranty though - to cover DOA and not obvious from first sight issues or early failures. And if it does break in the end, you can buy again another laptop or two, and still spend less that what a single new laptop would've costed you.

I've been using Prime on a Fire stick for a few months now with a US IP, using unlocator smartdns.  It works very well!   
In order to set up the account without having a US-issued credit card, I had to buy myself a Prime gift card and create a new account using that card, while connected to a VPN.  It's a bit complicated but I think it was worth the effort.   
There are a few issues related to not having a US-issues credit card... 1) you can't buy anything.  So you can only watch things on Prime.  2) you can't even buy free things - some videos on there are free, but not part of Prime.  Even these require a credit card.

Yes - incredibly they are.   
The card automatically comes with a UK#, which will always remain active. Other local numbers are free of charge for up to a month. If you want to keep a local number permanently, it´s £ 5/year.   
Catch#1: 
The UK# is a Lyca#, which are (strangely) sometimes more expensive to call than "normal" UK mobile #s. If you need a UK#, I recommend porting a "normal" UK# to the Togglecard. I did that successfully    
Catch#2: 
Lyca/Toggle doesn´t allow to activate any call diverts. So if you travel to a country which Toggle doesn´t support, you´re in a pretty dire situation. (There are workarounds, but they´re pretty complicated)   
Catch#3: 
Outside of the UK Data is pretty expensive.   
Because of all the catches I don´t use it as my main#, but it still opens many opportunities.

post: I get the impression that the following may also work without a wifi network, but bb2 (or any other user) would need to confirm.                My 8yr. old finds loads of kids programs and films on YT on her tablet and watches on the telly via Chromecast. YT is still a good resource for kiddie stuff. I never cease to be amazed at what folks will upload.      I predominantly use mine just for my Zattoo recordings - it's much better to use than the Smart TV app.

I switched to Swisscom fibre after Cablecom and can confirm I no-longer need to pay the Kablelanschluss fee of about 30chf. However, if you do pay the Anschluss fee, Cablecom may still sell you a modem with 0chf monthly charges. Basically a freebie to stop you closing off the Anschluss, as they still make money that way. So the cheapest package is about 30chf (Anchluss fee paid in your Nebenkosten). Cablecom service depends on the quality of the cabling in the houseIf it is an old house, you can end up with non-stop problems from Cablecom.   
Fibre packages have the lowest latency (eg 1ms Swisscom), if you take 1 level above basic, otherwise it is 5ms or so on the basic Swisscom package. At the cheapest end, Swisscom fibre is pretty good because of the low latencies.   
WWZ and Cablecom cable seem to come in around 10ms latency.   
I recently took out a Salt Mobile 4G Internet contract. This is unlimited internet, download speed varies, but seems to be up to 7mbps down, 2mbps up, more or less the same as entry level cable or Swisscom Fibre, latency seems to be between 35 and 70ms, using my phone as a hotspot. If you are not gaming or trading this might do for home as the latency is probably not noticeable. The monthly cost for unlimited, with 2 SIM cards is 60chf, about the same as a low end Swisscom Fibre package. The cheapest internet out there seems to be a Sunrise PAYG for 7.5chf monthly 250mb on a phone sim 4G, or 15chf monthly for 3g on a data only sim with 1GB download limit at 3G, then after that something painfully slow like 300k, almost but not quite unusable.

Right now it's a crazy offer:       
For €9.99 you get pretty much the same as per first post.

You actually do not own UPC equipment, which is why it must be returned.    
When the equipment was sent to you, they should have provided a postage paid reply label. If you kept the box you can use it to send it back, or you can use any box.    
They are also accept the equipment back at their sales centres.       Do not throw anything away until UPC have confirmed receipt of the returned equipment.   
We have more than one UPC box, but for example the internet only runs from one. Each box is under its own contract. Also, the replay feature on the boxes is not identical. The box which is less expensive has a shorter replay capability.

post:
So my building got connected to fibre end of February 2016 and I weighed my options:    
- stick with Citycable and pay through the nose to go from 300/20Mbps (80CHF) to 1000/50Mbps (extra 20CHF)  or to symetrical 1Gbps for another 15CHF a month, so a total of 115CHF a month. And that's before you throw in tv stuff. Free installation of OTO box.   
- go for the wingo offer of symetrical 250Mbps at 75CHF/month. Free installation of OTO box.    
- or since I live in Lausanne, go for Saitis.net, a tiny local ISP run by some ubergeeks I used to know back in the day. They offer 1Gbps symetrical for 1000CHF/year or 269CHF/trimester. Which is incredibly cheap! And you get a fixed IP with reverse DNS delegation (important for IRC bragging) and IPV6. This is available    
I ordered saitis.net in mid April and the technician came to my place on the 1st of June (the date I'd chosen for installation) and took about 4 hours to do the cabling and fit the OTO box. Cost: 155 CHF. It's best effort but it works. You need the Fiber7 kit, same as with init7 in Zurich.   
But the connection didn't work as I wasn't getting the DHCP lease. Contacted support and 2 days later (this is a really small op) they checked at the Telco Datacenter and the technician had connected me to VTX instead of Saitis. Once that was fixed I got the a working connexion and speed is pretty damn good.  I still have the Citycable connection+tv box and will decide if that goes down to 2Mbps with TV or just get the cable connection completely cancelled.    
Feel free to ask questions!

post:
Yes, the power plugs are different from the North American style. Bring a few US power bars with you, you can change the male plug to a Swiss one, but leave all your components with the originals. Anything that is a media or computer device will generally have a dual voltage power supply built in. Bring at least one power bar for every room, the travel converter plugs are ok when you are on vacation, but it gets old pretty quickly if you are in for the long haul.       
Signal connectors are pretty universal, RCA for audio/video, HDMI, F Coax etc. Although there were a few European connectors (Scart, 5 pin integrated audio) that aren't common in North America, these would only make a difference if you were trying to interface your components with a European Amp or Pre amp, which is pretty unlikely.

post:
Well if it's wifi it's clear you understood incorrectly how it works and what are the conditions to reach the alleged top speed.   
Try to cable and see the speed...   
See random website information:     
In order to get fast speed with wifi you need a lot of things, starting from the right AC wifi device on your computers, the right amount of antennas, the right distance, the right compatible standards between your client and the router, no channel overloading, etc....   
While it's true the latest wifi receivers can go really fast, it implies lot of things (4 external antennas, compatible with high end router, etc...).   
Additionally, with your TWG870UG, it's possible it has little amount of internal antennas, possibly weak chipset, etc...     
In other word, if you want to be sure to have a given speed, you need to do the homework and verify accurately all your wifi chipsets on your laptops, vs the wifi router/modem chipset.   
I could not quickly find the specs of "TWG870UG", but I found an older TWG870:   . 
You can see the standards it supports, amount of internal antennas, etc...   
Do the research!   
Maybe you'll find that there are a better combination out there between X modem/router and your laptops. In details, it's the wifi AC standard (latest being 802.11AC), the amount of antennas everywhere (to get more MIMO streams), the compatibility between the chipsets, and a few other details like the physical setup, range, channel saturation...

GGA is the cable TV provider in you area.

The bill itself seems reasonably/fairly low as often you get billed the actual work time spent plus some predefined time to get to the customer and back, like half an hour. However 100CHF straight could be some predefined amount, e.g. simply because the technician got called regardless of how his efforts and time spent.   
Ask the technician what the actual cause was, there's a good chance he still remembers or took notes. Talk to the co-owners, find out if you are the only one.   
It may be useful to upload a scan of the invoice (personal info removed of course).

post:
Hi,   
[Edit: I only saw you've already bought a laptop after I posted, but leaving it here as possible advice for others interested in the same thing  ]   
Have you looked at Amazon UK? They do send at least some laptops to Switzerland, and take care of customs for you (so you don't pay anything yourself). I've done it as well from Amazon US without any problem, though for some reason it's harder to find laptops that Amazon ships from the US to Switzerland.   
Just make sure it's sold by Amazon itself and not an external seller, and that you see "Import Fees Deposit" in the final checkout page. This is what Amazon will pay to the Swiss customs for you, so you don't have to pay anything yourself. The program is called  .   
But as an aside, I've been using a Swiss laptop with a US keyboard layout without any problems. I touch type, so having the wrong labels is not a problem for me - if you touch type as well, give it a try.   
The only thing that changes is that the enter key is two lines instead of one, which moves the "\" key (that in US layout is above Enter) as well. But it's not a big deal, and it's actually much easier to use than I expected.   
Hope it helps!

Do you live near the border? Had a smiliar issue when I was still on Sunrise. Turns out that these boxes have a built-in dead switch if they detect that they're in a different country (they're not allowed to run these outside of Switzerland). So if your local Sunrise antenna is on the fritz, your box might detect a foreign cell signal and kill the connection.    
We live right on the border to Germany - during the first three weeks I had this thing, it just wouldn't work. I called tech support over and over again, they just couldn't figure out what was going on. Eventually, someone told me the last thing they can do is to disable this foreign cell network thing - and bam, it worked.

The difference between UK/Irish plugs is that the Earth pin is in the plug and is there if it's needed or not. Most televisions (or all the ones I have seen) don't even use earth (you can tell by the flat cable). So your mate's TV blowing up in my opinion is a coincidence. Sockets in all of Europe do have earth sockets, but it may not be obvious to travellers because they mostly use the "Europlug" standard:   -- a plug that fits in all European sockets (except UK/Ireland without being forced). For your information, there's two main types of sockets in Europe; the French and then the German. Then there's separate Swiss, Danish, Italian and British sockets:

post: Apparently google doesn't work for people new to Switzerland.

I use Google Voice --    You would need to use a US VPN or proxy to initialize it, as the option to sign up only shows up when you are using an American IP address.  You can then call out or receive incoming calls via Google Hangouts, or use a VOIP adapter like ObiTalk:    I also use LocalPhone,   -- where I have Swiss and US DIDs, and their rates are very competitive. I have travelled the world, and have my DIDs forward to my local mobile.  E.g. the charge to forward/call to Swiss mobile is 11.9¢ (US cents).   Also for a VoIP client, I would highly recommend Zoiper,    I also have Asterisk and FreeSwitch servers on Amazon cloud,  so I can have an IVR, and use FlowRoute and VoIP.ms for my SIP trunks.   
Also, CallCentric offers free NY DIDs   - Just sign up with a non-US address, 
so you would not be subject to E911 fees.

post:
And that's exactly it. 
 It reminds me of going through the radio times with my gran who was housebound for most of my childhood and who died when I was 11. 
The Christmas radio times would arrive and we would go through it together and she would mark the things she wanted (and didn't) want to watch at the times she was at home alone over the Christmas period. 
It was in the days before video recorders etc so if you didn't watch it when it was on you didn't see it and she always complained about them messing about with her regular programmes at Christmas.   
So for me it's a childhood memory that I still like to do today as it reminds me of her and an online version wouldn't be the same. We rarely actually watch the things we've highlighted but that's not the point for me, it's the act if doing it that's important.   
So yes in response to Carlos R it is still one of the best bits of Christmas for me even now and it brings a tear to my eye just thinking if it.

Hi TiMow,   
I've set up a little home cinema in a 5x3 meters room using the   short-distance projector.    
Based on what you write, I think it would also be a great fit for you. It's FullHD and it throws a 2 meters wide image from 1 meter distance (see attachment).   
No matter what people say about the optimum viewing distance/screen size ratio, I totally enjoy the big, high-quality display even from 3 meters distance. And of course, high resolution rocks! I wouldn't go for less than 1080p if you'd like to have a halfway decent home theater.   
I also appreciate that the GT1080 has 2800 ANSI lumens, two HDMI ports (one of them is MHL-capable for smartphone connectivity) and quite a long lamp life of ~6000 hours.    
The noise level is quite low (26dB in Eco mode). And since the projector is close to the opposite wall and NOT above my head, it's even more silent than using a long-throw setup.    
The integrated speaker is alright, but I'm using a Teufel sound system instead.   
Currently, you can get the projector for Back then, I ordered it from Amazon and picked it up at the border to save the German VAT.

post:
An aging battery can be source of much pain, so you are doing good looking for replacement.   
My source for battery purchase is   (which gives you nice implicit filtering for delivery from, e.g., the UK or Germany to Switzerland).   
As it happens, I bought an additional battery for a Galaxy Note 3 many months ago from France - reportedly genuine, priced OEM. That battery still performs however genuine it might be.   
If you purchase from Amazon directly (i.e. not market place) you should be pretty safe when it comes to counterfeit product (in case you care).   
Just go hunting for a seller who seems to be trading _a lot_ of batteries, with a very good reputation, and do not go for dirt-dirt-cheap.   
Something around CHF 15 delivered should get you a decent enough OEM battery.

bought the Google Chromecast audio dongle today for 39 - 6 tax back and I am really pleased with it.   
Just a few tips: The only audio cable it will only be useful if you have a hifi with an aux connection that expects one 3.5mm input otherwise you will need to an RCA Audio jack to split it into two cables.   
There is a setting in the Chromecast app for HDR (high dynamic range) which by default is switched off but if you are using a decent audio system system you will want to switch it on...their warning for this setting is:   
Note:  Many common speaker systems such as desktop computer speakers, docking speakers, portable and Bluetooth speakers are not built to support such a high dynamic range, causing the volume level to be very loud and sound to be somewhat distorted. Please avoid turning this setting on in those cases.   
If you want to the digital signal directly then you will probably need a mini TOS to standard TOS connection as it uses the same socket as the standard audio cable.    
Playing Google Music and Pandora using the digital connection to a Sony Soundbar it was really impressive and not compressed as sadly a lot of MP3 music sounds.   
I also cast the audio directly from phone to see how well it would work with Tidal. Not as good as with Google Music but still really good.   
One tip don't forget to switch off casting from the app when you are finished otherwise even if the amplifier is switched the device will continue to stream music. I noticed this when I switched everything off...went out came back switched the amp back on and it immediately played music from Pandora even though the amp had been switched off and my phone had been with me.     
Very pleased with my purchase.   
Have fun   
Martin

post:
I posted a while back, because I wanted to set up and home network with UK VPN available selectively across the home network.  I thought I would share my solution since it required a lot of interweb trawling and fiddling around.  UPC Cablecom is the provider.   
1. Update UPC Modem to Technicolor model, as this is the only one to support bridge mode 
2. ASUS DD-WRT capable modem, in my case AC68U, install ASUSWRT-Merlin firmware 
3. Set up the router VPN client with the OpenVPN configuration from your VPN provider, Im using ExpressVPN 
3. Decide what devices you want to have permanently on the VPN, assign static IPs to those devices, for example Roku media server running iPlayer 
4. Set the Redirect Internet Traffic to Policy Rules and add those IPs as Source IPs designated to go via the VPN 
5. Set up VPN Client software on devices such as PC's and iPads that you want to be able to use VPN selectively with.   
Simples.   
Im sure there are slicker setups involving more tinkering for those who are really happy with advanced network routing settings and DDWRT scripting, but this provides a stable setup using just the GUI's, a very simple firmware update, and setting up a few devices with static IPs.   
I switched from StrongVPN to ExpressVPN, because the PC and iOS clients are much slicker, allowing for quick changes eg between UK and US servers.   
Hope this helps.

Do you know the person, or just the IP. Your initial statement was vague. Also, is the IP in Switzerland?   
With regards to ongoing security, do you have any idea how they got your password? If they got it by, say, hacking your computer, then you need to clean that up before trusting the computer again. By "clean that up" I mean to reformat and reinstall everything.   
Fortunately, the most common way for a gmail account to be "hacked" is when somebody uses the same password for both gmail and some other website. Then the other website is hacked and all the passwords stolen. So, if you did reuse your password, you probably don't need to clean up your computer, but you do need to change the password everywhere it was used, preferably without re-use.   
You also should at least check the password of any website accounts which know about the gmail address - if access to gmail let them reset passwords, they might have done so and deleted the resulting email chain.   
P.S. In addition to not re-using passwords, you can turn on   for the account. This is slightly less convenient and you have to be careful not to lock yourself out if you lose your phone (I keep a printout of recovery codes locked up somewhere safe.), but it makes your account quite a bit safer.

post: Mobile phone roaming agreements are very much different from content right management issues. It would need bilateral treaties for Switzerland to participate in such an open-trade environment. post:
Hi guys, can only talk to my experiences.   
No port blocking, restriction of VoIP services when using either of the carriers mentioned (prepay services) (since March)   
For example, FaceTime, Skype, Google Hangouts all work fine on mobile data out and about, to such a point where I commit all my credit towards data, I don't make any phone calls/txt's of any kind - my phone calls are done entirely through the use of these apps.    
Agree that the device needs to be unlocked etc, a purchase outright of any phone should come that way anyway (provided you don't purchase through a carrier).    
Suprisingly using data for calls is quite affordable. A regular 5min call is a fraction of a cost through a Voip service compared with call rates and uses 5-10MB which is minimal. A 15CHF 1gb plan is lasting me about a month if frugal, (no hotspot and using wifi at all opportunities) so it's doable.    
Perhaps Sunrise and Salt will introduce restrictions to how data is used but at least this way they are driving up the use of data services. I also believe data restrictions on VoIP and charging for hotspots is a bit yesteryear, certainly in Australia anyway where this was the norm a few years ago.  Competitive carriers with introduction of 4g have removed all that nonsense and we've been free to use data however for a little while now.

Thanks for the tip to beware of fakes. I only saw the Rikomagic stick at no-name online shops so far so I'll look further for a reliable source.   
And that's the second time this week that I saw a warning about counterfeits of a brand-name product. Don't tell me that faking is now spreading beyond dodgy Rolex watches and designer handbags - too many 3D printers out there.

Update....   
The blu-ray DVDs (Justified Season 4 and 5) arrived and I could NOT watch them on my blu-ray player. Error message said "wrong region". Another blu-ray DVD bought at the same time for which Amazon also said "Region A/1" was in fact multi region. Conclusion: Region-specification on Amazon IS unreliable. AND: I was now sufficiently motivated to get me a A/1 player.   
So I started evaluating A/1 blu-ray players and voltage converters. After looking at various on-line shops I limited evaluation to Amazon, compared reviews, prices, (shipping) weights and shipping costs and finally went for:   
and   (the cheaper and lighter Simran-voltage converter suggested by monkeyboy76 was not an option as the seller did not offer international shipment - same as some other sellers)   
The whole lot cost me CHF 99 (player) + 30 (converter) + 32 (shipping) + 14 ("import fees deposit") = 175. But from experience I expected to be charged with some more cost when it arrives (taxes, VAT and whatever). But that didn't happen - the lot arrived yesterday, no further cost! Amazing...    
AND IT WORKS by the way...    
Thanks again for the helpful tips regarding voltage converter - that saved me a lot of time

I have a similar setup as Phil_MCR (and probably a few million others)   
RPi (not the 2, the first B+, no idea of the name) with XBMC, plus Transmision, Couchpotato and Sickrage. I have not big problems playing movies (no idea whether they are 4K, but some files are around 4Gb if that helps).   
I am using XBIAN in Raspberry. And I would say that running the whole setup (Transmission/Couchpotato/Sickrage/XBMC) is pushing a tiny bit the limits. So, although it works and do the job, I am not surprise that for me, managing those apps through web interface is a tad slow and there are few glitches here and there (for that I have a few scripts to restart, email and a monitor the system)   
I am trying now to free the load of the Raspberry and moving most of the apps to the NAS (QNAP) and leaving RPi just as media center (running Xbian XBMC/Kodi).   
Ah, for me I found it impossible to run RPi using WiFi (extremely slow) so I had to connect it to the router.   
I have considered replacing the RPi with CuBox:    
The system is running 24x7, and it gets hot, but is not noisy and I believe one of the advantages is that it does not consume much. One of the disadvantage (if you care) is that you end up having quite a mess of cables around

I set up an old busted up mac as a server, made an account available with acccess to WebDav, CalDav and CardDav. Used a dynamic DNS to point to my network.   
This can then syncronise all my contacts and calanders across all devices, plus I then use Goodreader to access my files from the WebDav account and from there pass them onto the relevant app.   
It's basically my homebrewed personal cloud, and works from wherever I have internet access.   
Naturally all connections are encrypted.

if you have a locked iphone, it is now possible to get it unlocked so that you can use any SIM. it's free to do if you're on anything apart from a pay as you go tariff (PAYG unlock is 15 quid).

once you're unlocked, you're good to go to use a Swiss prepaid SIM.

yes it does, in some apartments within a building block, the owner/tenet can decide not to pay the 29CHF monthly fee to have a cablecom socket enabled ( )hence they close it and forgo the fee, note this is nothing to do with the fee you pay for the internet/phone/TV from cablecom.   
you should contact cablecom again and ask them if the case above is indeed the situation, but your landloard should know as he/she most likely pays that fee or indeed authorised the cable disconnection.

My advice is to use VOIP for all calls!   
Even (especially) to Swiss landline and mobile calls. Just worry about the data, and not the international calls. Once you have a data allowance you can use VOIP with a SIP app.   
I use Sunrise Pay-as-you-go but when I last checked, Aldi had a better deal. The Sunrise data performance is good enough to use VOIP most places. 9chf gets 250mb monthly allowance which will do all my calls for a month, still leaving some for checking email in emergencies. A 2GB data topup with Sunrise is 19chf when needed and lasts a month. That combined with hotspot access free from a home ISP (eg Cablecom hotspots in most residential areas), friends WIFI's etc.   
VOIP uses surprisingly little data, but does need low latency and the power of a decent handset made in the last 3 years or so.   
voipcheap.co.uk on my mobile gives me most international landline calls for free (including Switzerland), most mobile calls for 2p per min, eg, UK, Germany. Swiss mobiles are a little more but not much.

Good evening,   
If you did not make any phone call or chargeable text message from your swiss Lebara line (once within 6 month period) you number will be automatically deactivate from the system.   
Unfortunately Lebara should not be able to reactivate this number but if it still on your balance more than CHF20 (CHF20 is the price for a balance transfer from old expired number to a new Lebara existing number) Lebara can transfer your old balance to a new Lebara number (this new number needs to be registred under the same name than the expired account, I mean yours, if not the transaction will be impossible).   
Ex 1 :  Old expired number 076*****5 with CHF 40 balance left. 
You can take the money back to your new existing Lebara number 076*****6 
at least : CHF20.   
Ex 2 : Old expired number 076*****5 with CHF15 blance left. 
You will lost this money as the balance was under CHF20, so, you cannot cover the fee for the transaction.   
I hope this explaination will help you    
Have a nice evening.

Amazon.de lets you deposit an estimated fee at checkout and that's final, whether or not Swiss customs examine the package.   
From Amazon.de  , which I studied when DHL screwed up and double charged me after I had paid the Amazon deposit:      When you go without a deposit, things change according to the carrier if your package is not duty-free: 
- Swiss Post will ask you for cash at delivery 
- UPS now asks you for cash at delivery 
- DHL and Fedex bill you separately after delivery (DHL charges Custom expenses plus a 19CHF fixed fee per delivery)   
In my experience (Blu ray boxsets, PS4 games, etc) I was never charged for things costing less than 50 Euros (ordered individually of course), regardless of their provenance (usually UK or DE)

post:
You need to be a little more specific on the device you use and the plan you use, but here goes a swing in the dark:    
- beep every minute or so: you have enabled call counter, which alerts you on the increasing duration of the call (and fees) 
- three short beeps in the beginning of the call: you have enabled function alerting you to outgoing, as in out-of-swisscom-network calls. This is used when you call a 079* number which has been ported to a different carrier and you are alerted to the fact this is no longer swisscom estate.  
- beep resembling ongoing ring signal: attempt to power off phone, take out sim card; if device allows it remove battery, too. If battery is removable, press and hold power button without battery to eliminate any residual charge. If battery is enclosed, wait for a few minutes with SIM out. Insert SIM, insert battery, power on. SIM should initialize a fresh connection, ditto for your device.    
If all above fails: go to the nearest swisscom shop and ask if they are spying on you. Tell them a free iPhone6/Xperia Z3/insert-random-device will calm your worries. Report back.

post:
I had a similar problem in my apartment, if I plugged the modem in my living room where the main coax was, it working fine, but if I would move it to another room where there was a slave coax cable, wouldn't work.    
Cablecom sent their technician who measured and noticed that the signal was weak on the second cable, the signal needed amplifier if you wanted to have the modem in the other room. The amplifier could go on top of the building (you will need permission from neighbors etc) or it could go where the main cable is. I decided to place an amplifier on the main cable because it gives me a clean space in my living room (the amplifier is in the wall and is not bigger than the modem). Since than the modem in the second room works no problem. I have a lot of stuff attached on the modem so it's really not possible to have it in the living room. I think the amplifier was around 100 something CHF. You might have the same problem.

First of all I would like to wish Mr Neil luck, well a hell of a lot of it.  He is going to need it and maybe some miracles.     
I don't know if he knows it yet but I believe that he has baught the mobile operator with the worst customer care in Switzerland, or maybe even Europe.     
Why do I say that?  Well from personal experience.     
I have been a customer of Orange UK, O2, BT, Virgin France, Vodafone UK, Vodaphone Ireland, Virgin UK, Swisscom, Sunrise, Cablecom, Green.ch, Lebara UK, Lebara CH, O2 Ireland and a few more.  But I have never felt that Orange CH wanted to keep me as a customer.    
Many people I speak to also say the same.     
In 2014 Orange failed to do the following;   
1 To provide a usable 3G reception in my office in Lausanne.  In fact I regularly received SMS messages welcoming me to France.  They might as well have given my a million minutes, and 20 Terabytes, I could never have used it.     
2 To bill me correctly.     
3 Deliver an iPhone I ordered on their call centre.     
4 To cancel my order so I could pick it up in an Orange shop in Lausanne.   
5 To move my number to another operator in one month (after I gave up on Orange).     
6 To give me credible reasons why number 5 wasn't done.     
7 To give me the customer service manager's name so I could complain directly to them.   
I still am a Swisscom customer.  I have to say their customer care is second to none.  It is easily the best I have ever seen in Europe.  They are professional, punctual, polite, competent and they do what they say they will do.     
They are a little expensive, but which would you rather, an expensive service with unlimited minutes and data that works almost everywhere in Switzerland, and 1st class customer care, ----- or something less.   
Please reply.  It is important that you share your experience as well.

We have Apple Tv in both of our houses in Switzerland and France.  You can rent movies that have just come out on DVD or buy movies that have just come out in the theaters.  Everything's in English.  All of the US TV series are current up to the last season.     
Our regular TV runs off the Slingbox/Slingcatcher system, but this requires that you have a cable TV system somewhere available to you in the US.  This system "slings" your cable system from the US directly to your computer or TV over here.  The only problem with this system is that if you watch live TV, you are watching 6 hours behind.  (We never do this:  we tape everything, which is the most important function of this system, in my opinion.)   
So, I have to watch The Walking Dead on Monday morning, instead of Sunday night, but it's really only a slight inconvenience.

As part of a comms rationalization and cost-cutting exercise, I'm about to become the owner of a nice shiny iPad Air 2 (yeah, it took me ages to get my head round the idea that a new toy will actually enable me to save around CHF 80 per month with no upfront costs).    
In addition to the basics such as Evernote, Dropbox and the iOS versions of various business tools, I have already thought of MS Office and Noteshelf to acquire. A mobile network will never be able to compete with a cable TV network (or a fiber optic network) in a fixed environment.   
With upc cablecom cable TV you can currently have 150 Mbps download speed all the time, and it doesn't matter if the fridge door is open, the blinds are down, or if some just walked past in their chain mail underwear.   
Where mobile beats cable hands down is a mobile environment: you can have internet in your car, on the train, in the toilet, or hanging off the clock face of Big Ben.

SMSes are VERY reliable (>99.999% delivery), and they use signalling channel for delivery.  Which means that the message goes through even in case of overload on the air interface.    
Where the delay happens (where the bottleneck is) is usually SMSC.  It is a server for sending (and perhaps storing messages for later delivery).   I said "usually", but it depends from operator to operator.     You will notice that in times of peak SMS traffic (e.g. New Year's eve) the messages are delayed, since they are queued.     
The problem happens sometimes, when the number portability is used (i.e. number ported from one network to another).  Happens from time to time.

post:
basically BC paid for phones4u with debt and some equity. later on, they issued ~£205m in PIK notes and paid themselves a dividend of around £230m which paid back their investment and made them £30m, thankyouverymuch.   
net debt went up to 2.2x EBIDTA, 4 times more than before the BC acquisition. unsurprisingly, suppliers such as vodafone were not too enamoured with dealing with such a high risk company no longer able to offer competitive terms.   
not long after, the PIK notes became worthless (say goodbye to your £200m investors) and it looks like the senior bondholders are also going to be shafted along with most of the other creditors (say goodbye to another ~£430m or so).   
well done, BC. you really manage to sucker everybody including the investors, employees and the tax man.

Yesterday I walked into Coop and on my iPhone lock screen the supercard icon came up in the bottom left part of the screen, allowing you to access directly the Supercard app (or prompt you to install it from the App Store).   
Little did I know, this is a new feature of iOS 8 called App suggestions, which obviously work by detecting your location.   
In case you want to disable it, it is under Settings-->General-->Handoff & Suggested Apps.   
Also, if you are running the beta of OS X Yosemite, now you can answer a phone call from your Mac when both devices are on the same Wi-Fi network. To disable this, go to Mac Preferences-->General--> Uncheck "Handoff". 
This feature is supposed to work on your iPad as well (and in October you should be able to use the iPad for SMS as well as iMessages).

Do you know if it is easier to connect to orange ch in the centre of the city? I'm on the outskirts at home now which might be why I can only connect to sunrise. I get no signal with Swisscom here too.

TV's and some other consumer electronics are often dual voltage so the only thing required may be a new cable or a plug adapter (check the label on the back to make sure). BUT caution your Swiss TV may not be able to decipher the coding of the cable signal from a US cable company, even with the US card in the reader (different standard). You may be able to get around this by having a US cable box, I don't know, but you are probably better off selling the TV/DVD/BluRay entertainment center here and buying new/used in the US. The DVD/BluRay reader also needs to conform to the region of the world where you will buy/rent your disks. Alternatively you could purchase a region-free player which would play both your US and Swiss libraries.   
Also, be aware that things with electric motors in them (like a washing machine or a kitchen mixer) tend to get hot and wear out much faster on a transformer (which will itself get really hot) than if they were run on their native power source. So think hard about what the replacement costs in the US will be for such things, because you might find you have to pay for them soon anyway.

post:
Ok so here is what happened... tl:dr version, I went through with everything, but the security people were a bit unfriendly.   
Long version where I rant (it is not an exciting epic, so up to you if you waste your time).   
I went with PLENTY of time and go through security. Take the laptop out as usual.   
Pass once, they "rewind" the conveyor belt, ask me to take out what I had there. I took out the monitor (I decided to take it as well) as it was covering everything else, go through again, rewind, then take then, hard drive and DVD drivem go through again, rewind, and had to take also take motherboard out (I'm not sure why as by then it would be super visible in their scanner.   
Of course by then I have essentially all my suitcase literally "out of the bag". No problem, I was sort of expecting that from the airport security, they are just doing their job, not their fault for stupid policies.   
Now after the machine they have a bifurcation with two conveyor belts. I had like half my stuff on each side for some reason. I looked around and there were no tables where I could repack so I just stay there, but in order to be less of an hindrance I get all my stuff to the side that is used less and start repacking, started by putting all my stuff in just one of those plastic trays so I was taking less space.    
Now getting all my stuff carefully in there so it has a low risk to get damaged obviously takes a while. About halfway through the re-packing, a security lady comes looking a bit annoyed with me and starts talking to me gin French. I asked if she could speak English please. She then tells me that I can't be there, I'm taking too long, they need the space to do security checks on other luggage. I look around and there is plenty of space on the other conveyor and there is even another guy on the same conveyor as me, getting checked as well (I think he also had a bunch of electronics, but just tablets and stuff). I double check if there are any tables for re-packing in the area, but they hadn't magically materialized since I had looked before.   
So I go, friendliest as possible "Ok then, can you tell me where I should go to repack please?". I resist the temptation to make a snide remark, she doesn't look pleased but doesn't address me more. After a bit more I'm almost done and a new security lady arrives wearing a different uniform (I think she must have been some type of manager) and goes stand behind me with the other lady that had talked to me before. They talk in French with each other, I know a bit of French and I think they were discussing me.   
I finally finish packing in a somewhat satisfactory way, and say farewell to my lady escorts.   
Eventually on the gate area I seated down on a place with some tables and redid a bit of my luggage.

As of 20 August, prices have changed for  . I haven't seen or received any announcement - I found the change by sheer chance while using the website.   
You can see the new price list   and the old one  .   
For example, calling to a fixed line in the UK, France or Germany used to cost only the 0.29CHF connection fee, regardless of call duration. Now it will be 5Rp/min + connection fee. However, for some reason other countries (some of them fairly remote) still get the flat 0.29/call offer.   
Prices to mobile lines are lower now though.   
If you are a preexisting Lebara customer and you want to opt out of the new prices and keep the old ones, you can do it by sending an SMS with the text "STAY" to the number 255 before 1 January, 2015.

Why didn't you order the contract online? Their website is fully functional in English (if language was the issue) and it worked quite well in my experience (having started and renewed my contract several times, including once without any minimum duration).   
You could have signed a contract with no minimum duration, but in that case you would be paying the full price of the contract (as if you had got a subsidized phone). 
What you did is that you signed to stay for one year, and in exchange you got a monthly discount in your bill.  
Now if you want to cancel the contract there will be some penalty for this discount, but I'm afraid it will be higher that the money you have saved during these 8 months.    
The number to call is 0800 780 100 ( ). Good luck and let us know how much it will cost.

Hi - Hoping someone can make suggestions or have an opinion on a TV issue I currently have with WWZ.   
We arrived in Zug in September 2013 and I took the option of WWZ Quickline Platinum package from WWZ. 
We have three boxes you could say, 
In my office we have a cable modem type box , that I have a telephone base for a cordless telephone plugged into and also a CAT 5 cable to a wireless modem. 
The cable modem plugs into the wall via a coax cable that came with the cable modem. 
All works well ....Good fast internet link.   
In the front room ...sorry lounge , we have a Quickline TV box that is also plugged into a wall socket with a coax cable (I think) that came with the box and the TV connects to the Quickline box via a HDMI cable.   
All of above has been working well. 
But two weeks ago we noticed that the weather updates on the interactive page via the TV box were no longer updating. 
But the main issue is that the TV guide is also not updating. This means in a few days we would not be able record upcoming tv progs.   
Called WWZ and  did the normal power off....check cable ....etc 
They then sent an engineer to check the signal strength that the engineer did at the cable socket in wall end and via removing a panel in the ceiling in the utility room near the electric breaker switch area on wall below. 
All tests passed ok and she agreed we had an issue and told me to get box swapped (TV box unit). 
So I did via WWZ shop in Zug and on return to apartment ...wired in box and it went into menu and all worked well. After a few hours the local weather all updated (5 day forecast) and the TV schedule updated to allow us to look ahead 14 days. 
But ...but ...after 2 days it has given up the ghost again and is no longer updating Grrrrrr  
Last updates were on the 30th of July.   
I have swapped the coax cable with the one in office ....just in case, but no joy.   
Ideas ? 
Other than refusing to pay bill and ditching WWZ and moving to Swisscom :-)

I also had another curious problem that others might see. If I had the Thomson in "disabled" switch mode, yet had two connections on it, it seemed to cause problems for the Airport Extreme. Maybe it's because with switch mode disabled, using more than one connection doesn't make sense and the box was confused? I believe, with switch mode disabled, the Thomson should just pass the single WAN IP address on to the single connection (the Airport or other downstream router) and then the router takes care of the local network for everything else.   
I hope this helps someone else who might have this problem.

post:
Freeview is basically a service where you get a number of freely available channels at no cost, providing you have a TV/Set top box which has Digital signal capabilities. Freeview is not in itself a device, rather just a service which airs to devices. Many people may get confused because in the UK, boxes are marketed as Freeview boxes, but this is only because they either have no subscription capabilities or there is no subscription added (via TopUp TV CAM card). Using the set top box in Swiss would, in essence, make it a UPC Cablecom box, for example, adjusting for whoever gives you your standard digital signals (mine is Telecom Liechtenstein)   
So to the OP, no, you won't get Freeview in switzerland, but what should happen is that your Digital Box will scan for local channels - not channels belonging to Freeview - because Switzerland has different RF frequencies and also is not licenced to receive all UK channels.   
As another person said though, you can use Freesat here if you use a dish positioned correctly. The same applies with Sky Digital if you have an account and continue to pay - you can just simply position your dish very specifically to continue using.   
Information on Freeview and DVB-T, DVB-T2 (Both Terrestrial) and DVB-C (Cable) and also DVB-S (Satellite) can be found on the Ofcom website:

Orange is pretty big in the French-speaking part of Switzerland.        
In Geneva Airport is an Interdiscount shop, you can buy SIM cards from Orange, CoopMobile and a few others there     
CoopMobile also uses the Orange network, but maybe has better prices. You can buy the SIM card on-line or in most large Coop sotres, or Interdiscount:     
Oh, 3G is mainly on 2100Mhz (also some 900MHz), and 4G is mainly on 1800MHz (maybe some 2600MHz and 800Mhz). So check that whatever unlocked phone you plan to buy supports those bands, so you can have access to 3G/4G, otherwise you will be stuck on the 2G network, which is fine for voice, but slow for data.

Depends where you're going. In some countries they can easily and cheaply pursue the debt. Other than that you just won't be able to return to Switzerland. But there's a huge x-factor here. The world is becoming more and more interconnected, records shared etc. It may not be true now but in the future these records could easily be disclosed to other parties in your home country and affect your credit record. If you're going to run out on a debt - make it millions so it's worth your while. For a few hundred chf, just pay it.

Regardless of the little ego contest that seems to be happening in this thread (guys, surely you can find a mailing with Theo that's a better fit), changing your passwords too soon is as bad as not changing them at all in this case. If the server is is still vulnerable after you change the password (e.g. OpenSSL hasn't been patched, or keys haven't been changed, etc) then your new password is just as vulnerable to compromise.   
BBC was keeping a list of major services, their vulnerability and the patch status. If you want to be smart about it, look at that or a similar list and change your passwords on systems that have been fixed, one at a time.

Some of the older TV's do not have the ability (technology) to connect to newer routers. The simple reason for that is the security technology used in the TV does not support the newer WPA type "encoding" but only WEP.   
I would suggest you 1) try to connect using physical cable see if that works or 2) try to change the routers security to NON and then try to connect the TV, if it works then you know there is no issue with connection.   
Next step is to change the security to WEP (not all Wifi routers/access points have this option) but you can see if the encryption is the issue.   
if one of the solutions above work please let us know as this would help pinpoint the issue but if non work then its back to square one I am afraid.

You may want to check again the roaming prices of your provider. Looks like, they finally made it more attractive. I've been surprised this week end to find a package by Swisscom: 200mb for 24f. Not cheap but worth it. 
My gilfriend even got 10Mb free from orange.

It's really simple to understand: it is eactly like the old analogue TV days.   
Plug each TV into a socket and each TV works. Independently of all the other TVs.

thread: "Sitel SA" bill, separate from Cablecom bill.

post:
Hi,   
It is quite simple. There are the following ways to calculate a daily pro-rata:   
1) divide the monthly subscription amount to days in February (28 days) 
2) divide the monthly subscription amount to 31 days month 
3) divide the monthly subscription amount to 30 days month 
4) take the annual subscription fee (monthly * 12) and divide it to 365 days   
Obviously, the highest rate will come out if you choose February.   
Let's now take the example of "we_da_man" of a subscription worth CHF 65/month   
Option 1: 65 / 28 = CHF 2.321 per day pro-rata 
Option 2: 65 / 31 = CHF 2.096 per day pro-rata 
Option 3: 65 / 30 = CHF 2.166 per day pro-rata 
Option 4: 65 * 12 / 365 = CHF 2.136 per day pro-rata   
Therefore, they magically decided without no explicit reason to change the bill period exactly in February and calculate the highest daily pro-rata.   
So, 4 extra days in February * 2.321 = 9.284 + 65 = CHF 74.28.   
So far, so good, seems "correct". Also, I am not sure there is a specific law to address against the fact they decided to use the highest rate out of the 4 options. The most obvious one to have been used is the yearly average, which in turn would have produced:   
4 extra days in February * 2.136 = 8.544 + 65 = 73.54.   
There is a "small" difference of 0.74 rp, but multiply that with 1.5 Mio subscribers and you get roughly CHF 1'110'000 CHF extra revenue for Orange. Ok the number can be slightly different, but you got the idea.   
One will think what can be done to call justice upon the way they decided to pick up the month and the daily pro-rata.   
However, there is something more which is not easy to see. Everyone might think Orange is entitled to pick up whatever method they want out of the 4, HOWEVER:   
1. They could chose 6,7,8,9 as separate days in February (at the highest rate) + 10.02 - 09.03 monthly subscription, AS WELL AS they could chose 06.02 - 05.03 monthly subscription + 6,7,8,9 as separate days in March (at the lowest rate). And here is were I will ask in writing to Orange to change my billing period using THE SECOND OPTION, since is as valid as the first one (business wise as well as technical wise) and it is in my advantage, financially speaking.   
2. If they will not agree with the change of the bill, then according to their Terms and Conditions (See Section 12,    
"If you do not agree to essential changes to the Contract that are to your disadvantage you are entitled to terminate the Contract in writing within 30 days of receiving the notification."   
Therefore, I will ask for Contract Termination. As easy as that. The problem is that very few people will get it and ask for the money back, and they will remain with most of the dirty profit.   
Add that to profit made by adding CHF 2/month to paper bills in the middle of contracts (assume 30% of the 1.5 Mio subscribers where not switching to e-bill * 2 CHF = potential of CHF 1 Mio/month additional revenue).   
Add that to charging the internet usage for people in this overlapping days as pointed by someone above (assume you had 1Gb of free internet per month, they did not change that to 1 Gb + 142 Mb for the additional 4 days), add that to the free minutes you have, they did not increased the free minutes with a pro-rata, add that to the issues they had with their system and the fact that they charge weird internet usage (we had an incorrect amount of internet moved to the first day of the next bill) and you will get a picture of the ways to make money in our days.   
Well, be it onto them, according to what they do.

Yes, we had this FritzBox. Shame if this cannot be done with the technicolor modem. It is a very useful feature.   
Thanks.

After three months using this product, I think I can give an updated review.    
Internet speed is consistently 5 Mbps +/ 10%, no matter the time or the day of the week. It's more than enough for our everyday use, and as I said, enough for streaming HD video.   
The router is quite good. I have had a couple glitches though: once the Wi-fi started acting up but resetting it sorted it out. And one night the modem lost all connection, but the next morning it was working again.   
Thus, I haven't needed to speak to customer service, apparently one of Cablecom's weaknesses.   
Television is what it is. If I want to record, I do that on an HDD connected to the TV via USB. Of course, not having the Horizon box means you lose VoD and replay functions but I can live with that.    
I also got my first bill and everything seems to be correct. However, it annoys me that it takes them six days to create a PDF for the bill, by which time you have barely two weeks to pay it.

It won't solve your immediate problem but for future situations, you can vote for TunnelBear to add Swiss servers here:  . 
I use their service in the reverse direction and can heartily recommend it.

I have a Swiss and a US account. I never lived in the US and only have a couple of Swiss credit cards, so what I did was this: I opened a new account on of course a different e-mail address, filled in a fake US address (just looked up a random address on Google Maps; they never check unless they have to send you something, which they don't), chose "none" when prompted to enter credit card details, and then I bought (and still buy) vouchers off Ebay to buy stuff in the US store. Works like a charm.   
I'm sure it works the same for the UK store.    
If you have a UK/US/whatever credit card, you can save yourself the hassle of buying vouchers off Ebay. Even though "hassle" isn't the right word as it hardly is one - I always use the same seller and they send me the codes within 10 mins.    
I've had no trouble so far with updates either. I can also easily switch back and forth between my two accounts (though these days, I hardly use the Swiss one anymore anyway).

post: Quite simply rights restrictions. I would actually be happy to pay a reduced UK licence fee to listen to unrestricted bbc radio, and they could technically allow this using IP addressing.

As a follow up to my last post, they have recently upped the speeds of their packages and lowered the prices slightly e.g. my VDSL connection is now 40,000 / 4,000 kbit/s compared to 20,000/2,000 before.   
As my yearly renewal began approximately 2 weeks before they released the new packages, I paid the old price. I saw the new information on their website and had to request the upgrade myself. I had to make a follow up call a couple of weeks later but then they made the change quickly and without fuss.  I won't receive any refund on the money I already paid but I've now been here long enough to feel grateful that they did the upgrade and won't fight the ~CHF80 I 'lost'.   
In short, if you are still waiting on fibre or want to avoid cablecom, their packages are good value and from my experience very reliable. The only negative point is their customer service always feels a bit basic.

Tarif: 0 CHF/Min.   
Der Tarif von 0 CHF/Min. gilt während den ersten 15 Minuten des Anrufs auf die Festnetznummern der betreffenden Länder, auf MUCHO Nummern und auf maximal 5 vom Kunden im Voraus gewählten Schweizer Festnetznummern. 
4 Ab der 16. Minute : 0.15 CHF/Min. 
Verbindungsgebühr: 0.19 CHF pro angenommenen Anruf. 
Abrechnungstakt pro angebrochene Minute.

Logitech harmony.

You usually only need to convince the BBC (or whichever channel) you're in the UK whilst you open the page containing the media content.    
iPlayer has changed recently in that there's a few seconds of an intro before it reconnects to show the main program. Once the main program starts you can disconnect from your VPN (especially if you're using a free one with bad bandwidth) and watch directly.   
For the live content on BBC Sport it's more tricky. I've found I need to switch the proxy (from ON through the VPN or whatever to OFF/direct) whilst it's showing the "loading" spiral logo. Too early and you get a "can't be viewed in your location" error. Too late and "there is a problem with this video feed". I've got it sussed    
I have a domain hosted in the UK, and that provides telnet access to my account. Firefox (with the free putty telnet client) can route web traffic via this, which is based in the UK. However, I have such a cheap package they don't provide the bandwidth for watching hours of live TV, as I did over the weekend, hence my "switch it of at the right time" trick.   
This also works with the free Tor/Viledia "UK exit point" method - google for that. It's free but a bit more complex.
That'd be here:

It will work perfectly in Europe.   
In Canada it will work perfectly fine for calls on the GSM network. But no 3G network is 1900 only. 
You should completely avoid Telus and Bell as operators since they do not operate a GSM network (they use a different 2G technology) and their shared 3G network is not 1900-only. I recommend you to only choose amond the operators that appear to run a GSM network   and if I may "dictate" your operator, only use Rogers/Fido, or any operator with a national roaming agreement with Rogers.  
This way you will always have the GSM network to fall back to, and hopefully Rogers' 3G network will be deployed on 1900 MHz where you happen to go.

This was my first experience of online shopping with Microspot. I bought a mobile phone 2 weeks ago. Soon after the phone arrived, I discovered that it was defective, so I called them. They said that I should sent them back the phone for a reparation, and according to their policy it is not possible to change for a new one. I was surprised by that, since in any normal shop if a product arrives defective it will be exchanged directly for a new one rather than reparation. OK I admit that maybe this policy was written somewhere and I did not read it before making the order...   
So I sent them back the phone last week for a reparation. They said the repaired phone would arrive at my home this week. Then today I called up again, this time they said the phone is in the service center and they don't really know when it will be done, MAYBE in two weeks.   
Well, I am a little bit disappointed. Also, I paid the product 2 weeks ago and now I cannot use it. And all this is not my fault, and in the same time the price of the phone is dropping on their website (in the past two weeks it has dropped already by 30 CHF). So today on their hotline I also asked a reimbursement of the difference between the price that I paid and the price when the good-functioning product will arrive at my side. But the receptionist on the phone said she cannot decide this. she will ask and if they can do something they will contact me later (I think that they will simply not contact me at all).   
Well, my first experience with them, not so brilliant... Anyone else have similar experience with them?
Interdiscount on Sihlstrasse have one on demo.

Just to tell the end of the story...   
I took the media box and modem back to the service point in Renens on Saturday, who accepted it without a problem (even though it was minus the  
packaging).   
They couldn't do anything about the bill as they are 'not Cablecom'. However they could see my file and told me I was definitely listed as having cancelled my contract from October.   
So I rang up Cablecom today and asked them, very politely, to explain why I had  
a bill for November when I'd cancelled my contract.    
They explained, equally politely, that even though the bill said 'November' on the top it was actually October's bill, and directed me to the small print.   
After pointing out that that was a very confusing practice I accepted that I do indeed have to pay this bill, but was assured I would not be receiving any more.    
The upside of it is I am now 100% certain my contract has been cancelled.

Depends a little bit on what kind of content and functionality you want.  If it's mostly just text, I'd find a cheap website host and use Wordpress.  It's pretty powerful and extremely easy to maintain.   
Otherwise, I'd look into a more sophisticated CMS -- Drupal, for example, can be configured to do just about anything you want it to.     
With Drupal, you're more likely to have to dip into the code from time to time.  Wordpress is pretty much consumer-friendly now, with all the routine tasks automated down to a button-click.  (Gone are the days of importing modules via FTP -- now you just click 'install' and it's done automagically).

I use my UK cards when outside of Switzerland (I shop regularly just over the borders in France and Germany) - Nationwide for credit, Metro Bank for debit as they're both commission free on foreign currencies.   
In Switzerland I use my bank card (Postfinance) for debit and very rarely, my Halbtax Visa card for credit.  I usually buy everything on the debit card as interest rates here are too low to think about what the savings will be on a month's extra interest.   
You're doing well if you get a place big enough that you need the home plugs things.  Just get an additional wifi router which can work as an extender.  That's what I would do (not that I need such a thing in my 50sqm flat).   
Finally, when I've needed Cablecom support they've been excellent.

Rainy day today so I decided to compile into a post some data that I gathered when I started this thread.      
What I find interesting about these stats so far in 2013, is that the top 6 companies have been quite stable. 
It is only Samsung and Apple of course, and then the spots 3-5 have only been taken by LG and the 3 big Chinese guys (Lenovo, ZTE, Huawei). 
IDC and Strategy Analytics do not agree 100%, but this is because most companies do not announce their real sales so they have to estimate them (unlike Apple's or LG's numbers on which they agree).   
According to IDC it goes like this: 
Q1 - - - - Q2 - - - - Q3  
Samsung - Samsung - Samsung 
Apple - - Apple - - Apple  
LG - - - - LG - - - Huawei  
Huawei - - Lenovo - Lenovo  
ZTE - - - ZTE - - - LG    
According to Strategy Analytics it is like this: 
Q1 - - - - Q2 - - - - Q3  
Samsung - Samsung - Samsung 
Apple - - Apple - - Apple  
LG - - - -LG - - - -Huawei  
Huawei - -ZTE - - - LG 
ZTE - - - Huawei - -Lenovo    
It is interesting that only 6 companies are found in both these lists. 
In the past, and I am not exagerating at all, the spots 3 to 5 went to completely different companies from quarter to quarter, e.g. Sony, HTC, LG, ZTE and Huawei were in and out all the time while Nokia was slowly losing ground until it completely dissapeared.   
But now it looks like Sony and HTC cannot keep up with the Chinese invasion and only LG manages to survive in the top 5. 
Of course I cannot know how far from the top 5 they are, e.g. Sony may have been missing No5 for a few thousand devices, but since we only have the top 5 announced public, we can only make conclusions based on that.

Yea its a bit old but on the end of the info i found this..... So maybe not that bad if u only need to store the logs of email traffic not the content...     
Email surveillance   
Swiss legislation was changed in January 2002 to permit email surveillance 
ISPs had until April 1, 2003 to comply with technical changes required by law. 
Providers will have to keep electronic logs of email traffic for six months. 
Investigators will only be able to access data for specific criminal cases. 
ISPs will not log email content, but only basic data.

.... only phones?

Go to MediaMart, Fust, Migros Electronic, etc etc etc. They all sell them.      The bigger the dish the higher the price 
The more satellites you wish to receive the higher the price. 
If you want all possible satellites you may need to install multiple dishes. 
You can spend anything from 100 CHF to 1 million CHF.      Get permission from building owner to install the dish or dishes, then install them      Impossible. The fact that we live on a planet that is round and governed by laws of physics means you cannot receive signals from satellites you cannot see.   
Just like when the sun is on the other side of the planet you cannot se it, so is also true for satellite signals. You cannot receive signals you canno see.   
USA and South America are classic cases of countries where the satellite signal does not reach Europe.

My assumption would be that if you sign up for a contract that says 45 a month you will pay 45 a month for two years starting from the date of the new contract. This is a new offer to replace your old contract. As the chances are that your current contract will auto renew forever (unless a term in the contract fixes the discount period - you did read the contract you signed didn't you?) at 15 a month I wouldn't take this offer.   
For an extra 300 or so you can buy an unlocked one from Apple. It will hold its value better and you can sell it whenever you want to upgrade without worrying about it being tied to a contract.

Have been using them since the last Switzernet crisis, so about six months now.  Generally have no problems with call quality, customer service is highly responsive, rates are good. My only annoyance has been a few spam calls, from China and India, however since I dont get calls from those place normally I ignore, and if the same number calls twice I report these and they are blacklisted.   
In summary not perfect, and I wouldnt use as my sole phone number, but very cheap for outbound international traffic.   
PS If you are going to try them (there's no term contract, just prepay) let me give you a refer code

I had Cablecom in the past and paid for the whole package. I too thought the offering wasn't up to scratch so I cancelled their extras service. If you don't enjoy the service then just don't get it!   
With regards to paying 20 chf a month (I thought it was 30 but anyway, my flat mate organises bills payments), this is quite normal. It's called line rental, or the price for providing the basic service. If you were to cancel their digital tv/internet package you'd still have about 20 odd "free" channels. Often this fee is included in the charges for an apartment but not always. I believe Swisscom have a similar fee?       500 does seem a excessive if you are on the 86chf (+20chf) package.        I assume you rang up with your bills reference number querying exactly what each is for rather than a general I feel I'm paying too much rant when you rang them? If this doesn't (or didn't) get you anywhere then make photocopies of all your bills and send a registered letter to them asking for clarification.      While I've heard that netflix is great you'd still be stuck with the line rental and paying for an internet connection so at best you'd be cutting your bill from 86ch (+20) to 55 + 20 or along those lines. You could of course switch to swisscom but they are generally more expensive (though possibly a better customer service).   
Anyway you obviously have major problems with Cablecom so as you said it's time to find an alternative! All the best with your troubles!

You aven't stated where you are moving from, so I'm going to take a guess.       
OK, so you're moving here from Outer Mongolia. 
You'll find the iPhones sold in Outer Mongolia may not be the same as those sold in Europe. 
This means you may not get access to all the LTE frequency bands and may not be able to enjoy the maximum 4G bandwidths. 
This is one of the few limitations of the iPhone 5, there are a few different models made for different markets. 
(The iPhone 5S has less limitations, but is still made in different models for different markets)   
Otherwise, you can select any of the 3 existing Swiss mobile carriers and go and get a service from them. All offer iPhone compatible SIM cards, all offer pay-as-you-go and fixed-fee plans.    
Of course, you will need to ensure your phone is NOT SIM-locked. 
If it is currently SIM-locked to your current provider, call them and arrange for the unlocking before you depart from your current country. Depending on your current provider's policies, they may charge a fee to unlock.

I think the reason people don't use encryption is:   
1. It's too much a PITA to use; and 
2. They don't think it is that important to have their emails private   
It's also not simply a case of being useful for criminals. Some people don't feel comfortable having their privacy violated, or being constantly surveilled.   
I find it akin to people who have their homes robbed. Some people can brush it off and deal with it. Others find the intrusion really bothers them and have difficulty feeling comfortable in their own home afterwards. (It was for this reason Groklaw closed).   
You are right that a determined attacker can break into your email. But then, a determined thief can break into your house. There's a window that he can smash, yet, people still lock their front doors, right? Why inconvenience yourself with using locks and keys when you have windows in your home?   
I think the debate is really about scale. I guess most would recognise the need to monitor certain people with the right protections/court orders. It takes on a different tone when everybody is treated as a criminal and the monitoring is done illegally.

If you travel a lot and receive many calls in different countries, look at  .   
As a standard you have a British number on the SIM, but you can add a Swiss number (and some others)   for GBP 5 / year each.   
In Switzerland the card uses the Swisscom network, in Germany the Vodafone network. (Cannot yet tell about other countries).   
Incoming calls on all numbers (doesn´t matter which one) are free (Switzerland, USA, most of Western EU), cheap (Liechtenstein GBP 0.06) or affordable (0.19 for most of Eastern EU).   
In some countries, however, the service is damn-expensive, so it really matters on the mix of countries you need.   
If it suits your needs this card can slash a big chunk off your roaming charges!
