post:
I always see digitec recommended and I've used it before, so do check that option out.   
If you are buying something under CHF 300 maybe it could be worth getting it from Germany and deducting the VAT entirely.   
From my own experience, electronics are one of the few things that are actually cheaper in Switzerland... 
But I think one of the key reasons for that is that the VAT here is cheaper. If you buy it in Germany and it is under the limit, you could in theory recoup the VAT entirely.   
It may not make much of a difference though. I think Swiss VAT (MWSt) is 8% for electronics, where it would be 19%. So even if the difference for a CHF 300 item is just the 11% (it may not be), you would only be saving around CHF 33 for your added trouble.

A tax-refund depends on where you live. Citizenship has nothing to do with it.   
If you live in Bern and buy stuff in Switzerland, VAT is due. No refund possible, whatever your citizenship.   
If you live in Bern and buy things in the EU, you can get a VAT refund. I described the procedure for Germany  .

post:
Normally there is only one cable operator in town. 
So if you wish to use cable, you have only one operator to choose from: your local.   
Other alternatives to cable are copper-line technologies, from Swisscom and all the other wanna-bes that re-sell services over Swisscom copper (Sunrise, Green, etc etc etc)   
Swisscom are also rolling out fiber to the home (FTTH), check their website to see if it is available at your address   
So thats it: 
cable (one operator) 
copper (many operators) 
fiber (one or maybe 2 operators)   
Everything subject to the apartment being connected to the network

Sorry for the offtopic, but have you made sure the problem is on their side?   
Are you paying for 25 MB/s (Megabytes/s) or 25 Mb/s (Megabits/s). 
Are you getting 4 MB/s or 4 Mbit/s ?   
Are you connected to the modem/router with an Ethernet cable or WiFi?  
If it's the latter - this is the most likely reason for poor transfer. 4MB/s over WiFi would in fact be a not so bad result for an average user and it depends a lot on your environment (interference with other networks, microwaves ;-) etc ) and the distance from the router.

If you turned your mobile OFF then you shouldn't be charged anything.     
The local network in the country you're visiting should know your phone is off and when someone calls you, the network in the country your mobile is registered in diverts straight to voicemail, not bouncing in and out of the country you're visiting.   
That's how it's always worked for me.      
You should only be charged if your phone rings and you divert it to voicemail (either manually or automatically after a timeout).

post:
I bought the internet everywhere key from Orange a few years ago. It was a disaster.    
First off the person in the shop didn't take time to make sure I knew how to set it up properly. The sim card needed to be inserted into the USB key. Myself, my dad, my brother (who works in IT) all failed to open the USB key. That may make us sound thick, but it really wasn't clear. I had to take it all back to the shop and get the salesperson to do it. And he struggled too.    
Then the connection was rubbish. I once spent fifteen minutes just trying to load up google.    
Finally, the default 'homepage' was the orange internet everywhere page. It needed a log in, with a username and password, which I should have been provided - but guess what, I hadn't been. I went back to the shop, they showed me what they claimed was the username and password. Didn't work. At first I could circumvent this by just entering in a new web address. Then for no reason this stopped working. So I would load up the internet everywhere page and it would just sit there and demand this username and password.    
I was then told I needed to insert the simcard from the USB key into my orange phone in order to get my username and password. One slight problem. I didn't have an orange phone (and no-one had informed me I had to have an orange phone to use this service). We tried it in another phone. It asked for a code. We entered in all the codes we found on the packaging. None of them worked.    
At this point I decided to give up. The connection speed had never been great anyway, the customer service was poor and I just couldn't be bothered with any more faffing around.    
Not worth it. Poor instructions, poor connection, poor customer service.
I suppose they are trying to decrease the load on 3G and Edge. But I don't think this won't happen overnight. No so many LTE terminals.

post:
Wireless range is about the wireless chipset installed on your cable router (white thompson, allegedly), and antennas.   
In any case, a decent wifi router costs between 50chf and 100chf new.   
Here's an example:     
And here's the specs:     
Model:	Linksys EA3500 
Technology:	Wireless-N 
Bands:	Simultaneous 2.4 GHz and 5 Ghz 
Transmit/receive:	2 x 3 for 2.4 Ghz, 3 x 3 for 5 Ghz 
Antennas:	6 internal   
So you see it has the possibly to broadcast on 2 frequencies, and most importantly has separate transmit/receive and 6 internal antennas.   
Check the spec of your own router, I'll bet it's a poor chipset, poor antenna.   
If you want to go further, compare the actual chipset, but it's overkill...( )     
Anyway, with an "old" wifi router (7 years old), I still get very good coverage and speed. It has 6 internal antennas and also 2.4/5Ghz.     
Edit: Of course it also depends on your client, but you probably have any "intel wireless receiver", not much difference on the "receiving side"-

post:
I've had my Surface RT for a fortnight now and have to say I'm very impressed. Its a very nice piece of kit, as good as the iPad which is high praise indeed. When you see it in action you start to realise what the designers of Windows 8 have been trying to achieve with their much aligned desktop version...Windows 8 needs touch to really shine.   
What I love most about the Surface is of course MS Office, its as close to the full version as possible and has recently been upgraded from preview status. Together with the touch keyboard cover and mouse, it does feel like a very slick ultrabook. Youtube, Netflix etc.. look glorious on its 16:9 screen and most of the Apps I need are present e.g. Zinio, Pulse, Kayak, evernote, Netflix etc.. Some people say its better to get the intel based Surface Pro which runs full window 8, but I don't. The two are completely different, its like comparing a MacBook Air and an iPad. the RT is lighter, cheaper and has much better battery life than the Pro whilst offering the most equivalent experience. It sits in-between a laptop and a tablet.. its more like a tablet plus.

SF1 and SF2 are always unscrambled. If you are in German CH and your TV is showing the channels in original order after a normal digital scan, then you'll find SF1 ands SF2 on positions 1 and 2 respectively.    
You can at least verify proper reception of unscrambled signals like this.

What exactly are you looking for?! 
As mentioned QI is a great quizz, then the beeb has some really great series from Luther to Silent Witness, then theres the period dramas, or for comedy from PJ Wood house adaptations to Bluetone42. 
Not to mention the absolutely fantastically filmed remake 'The Lady Vanishes' and other one offs such as Dickens Great Expectations and The Mystery of Edwin Drood. 
Then all the wildlife documentaries, from frozen planet to blue planet, all world class, or perhaps you would like to learn something about science and space and watch the wonders of the Universe.  
Not to mention Top Gear, Ricky Gervis series Lifes short and of course the classic 'Office' 
And as for repeats, well unless you have seen every single old show, they will be new to you no? and besides, I can watch Black Adder and only fools and horse all day long and still enjoy them 
(and I actually enjoy the cooking shows  )   
As for advertisements on ITV, well yes, they have to make money, as it is a business, but they too do some good shows from Midsummer murders to Agatha Christie adaptations   
Yes there is crap too, but i dont see so many Swiss and German shows being so good they are either shown or adapted to other markets?   
You may not like the whole reality singing shows but a lot of the population all over the world, including Switzerland, do, hence everyone has some kind of idol/voice/talent show, as they do have cooking show too, once again adapted form the UK you have come dine with me.   
You really need to open your mind a little, broadcasters have to cater for everyone, hence its the easiest thing in the world to say its all crap, its not, its just not what YOU like, but wait long enough and soon they will produce a world class version of what you do want. 
You just cant have it every day all day.

Hello 
I have one of each in front of me right now and I can say the following:   
- If you like squarer laptops then Lenovo 
- If you like noisier laptops then Lenovo (and it's an i5 compared to the Dell i7) 
- If you have weaker eyesight then Lenovo - the Dell has smaller screen dimension and higher resolution - works well on Metro but in the desktop, it is testing...! 
- If you are looking at build quality, Dell is slightly better - this is because there is a little movement on the hinges of the Lenovo 
- Both have similar keyboards but the Dell has backlit keys 
- Both screens are lovely but the Dell has the full HD screen (1920x1080 versus 1600x900) 
- Both are around the same weight 
- Both have a lovely satin finish 
- Neither has built-in 3G   
You can't go wrong with either in my opinion but I'd choose the Dell ahead of the Lenovo (and actually just have).   
Please note that I'm fickle and once the Orange i7 is available, I might change my mind....!!

Most calls like this are scams, call-centers or something similar. The call-centre automatically dials random numbers and only if someone answers does it try to pass it on to one of the service agents. If no service agent is available, the system will hang-up on you (and this seems to happen about 90% of the time). 
In other words these are all junk phone calls any you aren't missing anything. If one day you actually have a human being on the line, speak to him/her in some made-up incomprehensible language. That gets rid of them fairly quickly.

post:
Sflowers,   
You can use a PC as "bridge" device as well, if it has two Ethernet adapters. Normally a wired one and a wireless.  You connect the PC to the VPN via the wired and then "bridge" the other Ethernet adapter (usually wireless) to it. All of your wireless devices connect to the PC just as they would a wireless router and the PC directs all their traffic over the VPN. Microsoft calls it "Internet sharing".    
Anyway, if that's too complicated, just use one of the DNS services instead.    
Dan

post:
I've finally arrived in Zurich and one of the first things I did was purchase mobile service and opened a PostFinance account all at the Zurich Airport Center.   
Before leaving the US, I switched the device of my Verizon line from the iPhone 5 I'm using now to an old iPhone 4 that another family member will use. This was all done online via the Verizon website.   
After arriving in Zurich, I went to the Zurich Aiport center and first went into the Swisscom shop to discuss their prepaid plan with one of the associates. Unfortunately, they did not have a nanosim that the iPhone 5 needs but they told me to go to the Post Office branch just opposite of the Swisscom shop where I should be able to purchase the prepaid plan and obtain a nanosim (this was a surprise to me as I didn't know the Swiss Post also deals with cellphones/mobile devices). Unfortunately, the Post Office also did not have any nanosims but I decided to open a PostFinance account while I was there (rather painlessly considering I'm a US citizen).   
So I went into the shop for Orange (also in the Airport Center) and they did have a nanosim. I got Orange World PrePay as mentioned by EdIsidor. I inserted the nanosim, tapped on the unlock SIM prompt on my phone and entered the pin that appears after you scratch it off the nanosim holder. The Orange associate had to enter 'click' without the quotes as the APN for cellular data. Within moments, my iPhone 5 is working on the Orange network! The data network is at 3G speeds and I was told 4G should start launching this summer.   
Aside from greetings, I did all of my talking with the employees in English (hopefully overtime I'll have a better handle of the language) and they seemed very friendly.   
For the short time I've used the cell service so far, it seems fine outdoors in the city of Zurich. When going indoors in Migros or COOP, my service fluctuated between 2-bars to no service. It was sufficient for me to get some translations on some product descriptions I was reading. In my studio flat, the signal is a solid 5 bars.     
I have a US Verizon Wireless iPhone 5 (Verizon sells the A1429 CDMA model) purchased under a 2-year contract that's still active. The phone is already unlocked as mentioned by several reports on the web but I've also confirmed this with Verizon as they did not have to go through the typical unlock process that I had to do with other global phones. I bought Orange World PrePay service and had a nanosim provided to me. With a little help from the shop associate, my iPhone 5 is now successfully on the Orange network.   
Hope this helps some people out, especially those coming from Verizon with an iP5!

post:
Hi all,   
I just wanted to post my experience as a newbie to Switzerland regarding payment of random invoices so save (hopefully) others from making the same mistake I did! I know that anyone who's been here longer than I have will probably put their head in their hands and think UH-DUH but here goes...   
Late last year we received an invoice (in German) from Cablecom for 3 months worth of "Service". I thought this strange considering we have TV/Internet with Swisscom. After google translating (my German is terrible), and researching on EF (obviously not thoroughly enough, all I came across, was Yep, you need to pay it) I figured it was for the physical cable connection that we had to pay "rent" or an initial connection for, so I paid it.   
Last week, I received another invoice from them. So I did what I should have done the first time, and called them to ask what it was about. After explaining the situation (that we have Swisscom TV through our Internet connection), they agreed to cancel the invoice, no worries. Very friendly service, no problems at all.   
Although once it was discovered that I paid the first invoice, it seems I have inadvertently signed up for a 12 month contract with them. So no cancellation now. They offered us a great deal to switch over to them, including paying out our cancellation to Swisscom among other discounts etc, but they don't have CBeeBies, haha.   
So, through not understanding processes properly in Switzerland, and not investigating properly (which I completely agree is self induced), we now have to pay 12 months to Cablecom for a TV port we don't even use.   
MORAL OF THE STORY:    
1.Don't pay anything just because you think it must be OK (DUH  )   
2. If you are using another provider and accessing your TV through the internet connection, and not the TV port, they will cancel the invoice over the phone.   
So just incase another newbie gets the same sort of scenario and comes across this thread, I hope it helps
thread: DON'T just pay Random Invoice for Service not requested

If you did a lock and wipe then all the data of the iMac's HD has been erased, and the computer has been locked out with a firmware password.    
To unlock the Mac hold the "alt" key down as soon as you turn the mac on, enter your password when you're prompted to. You can then attach your backup disk (actually it might be better to have it attached before hand) and boot from it. When booted you can use the "Time Machine" option to restore the iMac to it's last backed up condition.   
If you don't have the firmware password then you'll need to take the iMac to an Apple service provider to unlock it if it's a relatively new iMac. If its an old model you can bypass the firmwhere password by removing just one of the RAM DIMMS and then performing a PRAM reset (hold down cmd, opt, P, R as soon as you've turned the mac on)   
If you don't have a backup of your data then you're unfortunately SOL, as the lock and wipe overwrites the HD with zero's   
Let's hope it's not as serious as that as you've not been entirely clear on exactly what you've done.

On the main menu, select 'Picture' and scroll down to '3D'; (this was always unavailable, and I just assumed it was an app. only available to higher spec. models). However when a 3D program is being broadcast, it becomes active. Select it, then choose the image indicating side by side, and then OK.

I'd say it's more than a premium. Lets say you want to upgrade your iMac from a 1TB to a 2TB HD. Retail price for an off the shelf 2TB HD is around 100 - 130 for a standard desktop 3.5" HD. Apple's price for what would be exactly the same HD at end user price is around 600 chufs.   
Oh, and since 2009 all iMacs require a drive from Apple for the computer to function normally. Stick an off the shelf drive in one of these iMacs and after 5 mins of use all the fans in the machine will run at full speed.    
Apple buys drives from Seagate, WD, and Hitachi/Toshiba, but all the 3.5" drives have special firmware supposedly to supply the main board with temperature information in a manner that's more efficient than SMART, but in reality it's just seems to detect whether an Apple drive is present or not, and then make life uncomfortable for the user if it isn't an Apple drive. There are ways round this, but they generally involve shorting certain connections on the main board.   
Price gouging, there's an App le  for that.

post:
I see a lot of people looking for places where they can fix their broken iPhones/iPads/iThings in Switzerland for less, and unfortunately there are far too many people taking advantage of this locally.    
The thing with iDevice parts is that they're usually very cheap and they can be of very good quality if you get it from place at the right price. Pretty much all of the repair shops in Switzerland (and maaany other places aswell) provide their services at a significant markup, sometimes 5 or 10 times the price of the part itself. Although it can be justified by the fact that their time is expensive and that they need to pay bills, it's still overpriced in my opinion.    
On average, an iPhone 4 screen replacement job costs 100 CHF, with some going all the way up to 200 CHF and others being as low as 39 CHF. A cheap, low quality screen costs 18$, a high quality one costs 25-30$, and a completely original screen costs 55$, plus shipping. The level of how original the screen is is a very debatable subject. In my experience, the 25$ screens do the job just great, no one can tell the difference between the 'original' ones and the 25$ ones. However, the really cheap ones, a.k.a. the ones you will find on Ricardo/eBay for 'reasonable' prices, are quite fragile and of horrible quality. For example, I bought an iPhone 4S back cover from Ricardo for 21 CHF shipped, and the quality was just about the worst I've ever seen - the lens was plastic and scratched, and the glass wasn't stuck on properly. When I buy the same part from my supplier in China (for only 5$, mind you), the quality is like the original. It just stuns me to what extent some people are willing to go to make a little cash on some poor unexperienced people.    
Some repair places aren't even honest at all. I've had someone tell me a horror story where they payed just shy of 100 CHF to replace the glass on their kids' iPod touch, and they got it fixed, but the volume buttons stopped working after the repair. After getting confronted, they said it was his own fault. Not wanting to spend extra cash, he thought he'd fix it himself, and he bought the parts online. When opening the iPod, he broke the glass....    
Speaking of DIY repairs, here is my rule of thumb: if you don't tinker with electronics (either for fun or for work), don't do it. There are some exceptions, such as with super simple repairs (iPhone 4/4S battery cover replacement, battery replacement; iPhone 3G/3Gs screen replacement (if you have the entire screen, not just the glass, otherwise it's pretty challenging)), and if you're good with crafts or other DIY projects. However, DO NOT TRY TO REPLACE THE SCREEN ON YOUR iPAD... it will end in blood and a lot of wasted time + money, guaranteed (I have experience).    
If you're courageous enough, the best place to find instructions is on  . You're best of to buy parts on ebay within the EU, more specifically France or Germany (UK isn't that reliable for some reason). You also have to choose sellers based on their ratings (don't buy if they have a rep of under 99.6% or less than several hundred evaluations), not just the price. Don't forget the tools!   
Why am I writing about all of this? Well, it's because there are a lot of unknowing people getting seriously ripped off getting their iDevices repaired. Your best bet is to simply not break it  . I have my own repair side business, so I have plenty of experience with these things.    
It's kind of complicated, I know  , but feel free to contact me with any specific questions!

For me it's not creepy at all, I've always seen that service being offered.

I have contact konsumentenschutz.ch and I got this reply. for people also interested.    
Sorry it is in German.   Die  gesetzliche Garantie dauert ein Jahr, und zwar ab Lieferdatum. Für  bestimmte Marken oder Produkte gibt es auch längere Garantiezeiten. Doch  oft passiert das Umgekehrte: Es werden nur wenige Monate Garantie  gewährt. Deshalb lohnt es sich, beim Kauf nach der Garantiefrist zu  fragen und gegebenenfalls eine längere auszuhandeln. 
Auch wenn  die Garantiefrist ein Jahr beträgt, müssen Mängel rasch gerügt werden.  Das setzt voraus, dass man die Ware gleich nach Erhalt prüft. Unterlässt  man das, kann man Mängel, die von Anfang an bestanden haben, nicht mehr  geltend machen. 
Auch für versteckte Mängel gilt die vereinbarte  Garantie. Nur wenn der Verkäufer den Käufer absichtlich getäuscht hat,  kann ein Mangel auch nach der Garantiezeit noch geltend gemacht werden.  Der Käufer muss die absichtliche Täuschung aber beweisen. 
Gesetzesartikel: OR 210  
Link for OR http://www.admin.ch/ch/d/sr/220/a210.html

Hey All, 
I went for ICS on my own... Not ready for Jellybean just yet! 
All the Stock ROMs for GT P7300/P7310 are available on the below site.   
I went through a great tutorial available on below link to understand exactly what i was going to do. I recommend you do this as well. The link also provides all the necessary files in the toolkit.   
Initially, I flashed directly to US ICS version. However, this led to a problem. On locking the device and unlocking again, a garbled fuzzy display came up and it was impossible to work with the tablet. I have press the power button for a long time to restart the table. It worked till i locked the device again. 
Then I followed the instructions given by varun.c.jain and Castro to fix it 
The steps are listed below... 
 1. Flash with a stock US ROM (UELA3) using ODIN  -- My device got stuck in an endless reboot loop at this step. I just went on to the next step. 
 2. Wiping data/factory reset. I started my device once after this. The usual setup stuff like setting up the wifi and google account etc. 
 3. Flash with the ICS ROM (UELPB) using ODIN 
Seems to be working gr8 now. Thanks to all for the tips and suggestions.   
P.S. The reason I started a new thread was because I could not find the installation instructions from the old migros. Probably because they were were amongst the posts about the various deals. Maybe this thread can be used for all the upgrade related posts for this device.

Twice I have correctly cancelled a Sunrise mobile contract, and both times the service was switched off 10 days early! Difficult to fight them, but having no phone was a nasty revenge from them.

UPC has unveiled faster internet access for its consumer market, doubling its basic broadband speeds from today. 
New  customers are being offered 50Mb download speeds as an entry-level  package, up from 25Mb previously. The company is also offering 100Mb and  150Mb packages, eclipsing its previous top speed of 100Mb.   
Existing customers will be given the choice to upgrade to the higher  speed packages, at a typical cost of 3 per month for those on UPCs  broadband, TV and phone packages.   
UPC has invested more than 500 million in upgrading its network to  allow consumers get access to faster broadband. More than 500,000 homes  can access the services.   
UPC said it had identified a number of trends among consumers, with more  people using video and watching for longer, a trend that is expected to  grow in the coming years. 
Sales and marketing director Mark Coan  said the proliferation of devices such as tablets and smartphones was  driving the need for more bandwidth, and was behind UPCs decision to  increase the speeds on offer. Consumer bandwidth consumption is  exponential, Mr Coan said.    
The company also demonstrated what it said was the fastest internet  speeds in Ireland, recording downloads of more than 1.4 Gigabits per  second in a live demonstration using standard equipment. 
UPC's  announcement follows the publication of a broadband plan by the  Government, which outlined "ambitious" targets that included the  availability of 70-100Mbps broadband to at least 50 per cent of the  population within the Government's lifetime. It also said a further 20  per cent of the population should have access to 40Mbps, with a minimum  of 30Mbps available to all.

A Billag employee can tell you whatever he wants, but what counts is the law (and what's written on the Billag web site reflects the law far more closely than what the Billag employee told you).   
This is not a matter of opinion, Tom is wrong.   
(oh, and the talk was about the  , the Radio license is a separate matter, Radio and TV licenses are two separate licenses!)

a) The country is densly populated and has a lot of Swisscom exchanges, thus the distance between exchange and house is on average likely to be less of a concern   
b) Many households are cabled for cable TV, and almost every cable operator (of which there are more than 300) provide internet access over cable systems, and this can provide much higher speeds than DSL. eg: upc cablecom currently have 100 Mbps download as their fastest internet speed on their cable TV system   
So the majority of the population don't have issues with speed of internet access.

post:
Yes.      If you buy the receiver locally, it will be all set for Swiss power and power plugs.   
The video and audio cables are the same here as in the US: these days everything is HDMI   
Of course, you need to look at what connectors you have on your devices (Cinch, S-Video, Composite, HDMI, etc) and make sure the receiver you buy has enough inputs of enough flavours to make you happy.   
Of course, all your devices need to be able to run on Euro 220V, instead of USA 110V. Read the label on each device to see what it is happy with. 
And then you need a power plug adapter to fit the Swiss or Euro power points. See Interdiscount for such adapters.

Hi!    
We are leaving our place in Switzerland to do some traveling and so cancelled our UPC Cablecom subscription (two months notice, as they require). I know some have had real problems with Cablecom Customer Service but we have had actually good service, we have been happy with them.    
Unexpectedly they called us back to ask why we were canceling. When they found out we were just temporarily away they offered to "freeze" the account rather than canceling it. If we remain customers we have to pay one-time 10 SFr for this freezing service. Then when we restart the service in 2013 we do not pay any start up cost and will also get 50% the cost of our package for the first 6 months! Sounds almost too good to be true. They said this offer is for certain customers... who knows about that but we were prepared to cancel outright and they called us.    
We have their 3for2 combination package. This is my first posting - I thought this might be helpful for others and to ask if any one else had this offer. Apologies if this is old news.

I guess you just don't belong to the right segment for whom the box is targeted towards.   
The whole idea with a "blank" box is that it can be used for whatever the user want to use it for and therefor there is no manufacture-ready-out-of the-box for your specific needs/wants. The DB does everything you want it to do, but you need to know how...    
Besides, your example with the Sky box is a bit in the grey zone as you are not supposed to use your paid subscription card in any other devices than the Sky supplied box... Why? Amongst many factors, TV channels pay large amounts of money being at a specific position on the EPG and the DB let's you decide yourself where you want channels placed and Secondly, the recorded programs on the Sky box are still encrypted so only viewable with a live Sky card. The DB saves programs as de-crypted...   
PS. Yes I know, there are lots of things you are not supposed to do with your Sky subscription card and I don't follow all of the T&C's but I don't "steal" TV and pay Sky what they are due and have doen so over the last 20+ years

Based on that budget / use case, I'd recommend an Air plus external monitor and external storage for desk use at home. Like others have said, hang on for the rumoured imminent Air refresh though.

Last time I checked, my SGS III had massivle superior battery life compared to the iPhone 4S. Anyway, things like being able to sync the 1password reader or downloading Navigon maps in the background while I answer e-mails in the foreground are just convenient and, really, are something that I expect from a smartphone. I'm sure the ex-Nokia-crowd-now-iPhone-pros don't need that, though.    
My quarrels are with Apple, not with their products. I've always liked the iPhone for its simplicity and its design, that's why I bought and tried out every iteration. Mostly, I sold them again after a few months because they're simply boring.  
Android, on the other hand, I used to find frustrating. It was messy, unpleasant, but powerful. Lately, this has changed, however. With ICS and now with Jelly Bean, Android actually is a pleasure to use. Battery life is awesome, the cameras (on some phones) are excellent, the apps look good, the UI looks good. The Galaxy Nexus is the first smartphone I've had for longer than half a year. I now use a Galaxy Nexus (didn't want to sell it when I got the SGS III because I wanted the latest Android versions) and an SGS III. Sold my iPhone 4S 10 days ago.    
I can really see why both IT pros and the general ex-Nokia-crowd likes the iPHone. The IT pro doesn't want any issues with his or her phone after having solved issues all day. That was the reason why I switched to Mac OS as well - at that time, Mac OS was trouble free, open and different. I'm now in the process of switching back, because I made some massive career changes and don't work in IT anymore - and because I need a working version of MS Office. Now I don't mind installing Windows updates on my home computer anymore - something that used to give me palpitations after having fixed Windows computers all day. The ex-Nokias love the iPhone because it offers only basic functunality in a solid way. Just like their old Nokias. They don't really need a smartphone - but SMS and MMS looks all bubbly on the iPhone.

post: Well in order to have Swisscom digital tv, you will need to have a Swisscom phone line and a DSL subscription (the most basic version is PAYG) so if you are surfing with Orange it doesn't matter. You will however end up paying for a phone line (and the digital tv fees).

One of things you've got to take into account on this forum is that, regarding ISPs, for every positive you'll hear a negative.   
Cablecom had a bad reputation a few years ago, but I've heard that's improved quite a bit.   
Swisscom don't offer the speeds that Cablecom do, but you're more likely to hit the advertised maximum than with Cablecom - in any event Cablecom is likely to be faster, unless your in an abused cell.   
Sunrise is the slowest of the lot, and for historical reasons I'm with them, but I can say that I hit the max download rate every time, which is not difficult as I've still only a 5Mbps link  . That said it's fine for my usage as I don't torrent often, or stream HD, not to mention they appear to have very little downtime.
When I changed from a prepaid to a contract with Swisscom, the credit on my prepaid was deducted from the monthly payments.

I can understand that, but for me I tend to hit the bloody Tablet, so a FleX version was in some way better suited. Now I can really use Evernote!   
Pity they had no QWERTZ version.

Welcome to CH and to the forum.   
I am not quite sure what you mean by a Flashcard, there are calling cards but these are a little old-fashioned now as people have very good international calling rates available from people like Lebara and Yahoo (and I am sure many others which you can search the Forum for). These simply fit into most mobile phones, but for calling within CH you will be better off probably going for someone like Orange or Swisscom etc. Obviously don't forget Skype too.   
In terms of Wi-Fi coverage, it all depends on the router, if you were worried at all about the one that comes with Swisscom's coverage and as all your kids sound like thy are in Mac heaven you might want to consider an Airport Extreme - though I am sure others on here can recommend an equally good (and cheaper) alternative. We live in a three-bedroom house and have a rather aged Airport Express router which will support Skype from a different floor.   
Hope this helps, and you maybe get some feedback from a Swisscom user in Lausanne.

I've been doing regular data backups for nearly 15 years by now. First, it was CDs. I still have hundreds of them stashed away in various places (countries). Then, briefly, I used DVDs but it became a chore so I moved to external hard drives whene they dropped in price spectacularly. Now HDs are more expensive than they used to be 1 year ago but gradually going down again to the same levels as before the notorious Thai floods.   
Interestingly, Swiss HD prices apparently are one of the best. Even in Thailand itself or on Amazon UK they're more expensive. For example, I bought several portable 1TB WD Essentials for CHF99 here. Also, recently Melectronics had a similar offer for a 1TB Verbatim. Interdiscount had a 1.5TB LaCie for CHF149 and Manor had another 1.5TB LaCie for CHF150. These are all portable, i.e., not needing any power except for a sigle USB port.   
About USB ports, by the way. I had one expensive defective Asus laptop which declared support for USB3 but didn't actually implement it. So whenever I was plugging a USB3 drive into that supposedly USB3 port, it showed sympthoms similar to the ones described by the OP (Windows was recognizing new hardware but couldn't make it work). So it may well be a lack of drivers or a dying drive but could also be a USB3 issue.   
On the backup subject, I now only use external HDs since they're so affordable. I keep at least 2 copies in different places (countries) so I minimise chances of a fatal data loss. I did have 2 drives dying recently. One Buffalo (I think built on Toshiba drives) and the other Toshiba itself. Funnily, before that I thought of both brands as most reliable. I don't particularly, like WD (because they were second only to Maxtor in the league of most unreliable internal drives) but I have to admit their mobile dives didn't die yet. And one of them is like 5 years old now.   
Actually, I had 2 other victims on the HD arena - one desktop LaCie and one Seagate NAS drive. I don't use desktop drives anymore but I do have 2 NASes - primarily for accessibility rather than reliability.   
And yes, CDs aren't bullet-proof either. Some of those I burned 10 years ago are unreadable now.

I was going to ask how to change the speed dial in the phone app, but just chanced upon the solution. Searched google, youtube and here for a bit and didnt find a direct answer, so in case anyone else wants to know:    
Phone *5005*86*004178xxxxxx# where of course the last digits are YOUR number in international format.   
It feels like it does nothing (theres no voice prompt and you dont even know it connected), now try the speed dial. Et voila.

As jrspet is saying above (I think), it's likely (in fact, it's usual) that you have cable TV, supplied by your Gemeinde, included in your rent. If you don't want it, you have to have the outlet sealed (physically) by someone from the Gemeinde, and you will then get a reduction in your rent. However, you're usually charged a fee (of course) to seal the cable TV outlet ....   
It's very unlikely that your TV licence fee ("Billag") is included in your rent. You need to pay this directly to Billag.   
I can't help on the question about internet connection -- but that figure of CHF 40 sounds about right.   
Enjoy your new apartment!

post:
I agree with Nil on Vonage.  I have had a Vonage number since moving to Switzerland from the US, and I have been highly satisfied with it.   
In order to obtain the Vonage phone, I simply called Vonage (info at  ) when I would have normally called the local landline phone company to arrange for line disconnection when I moved out of my home in the US.  I was able to keep my old landline number.  I paid for the equipment from Vonage, received it via mail, and all was set. I would encourage you to make sure your bandwidth speed is high enough in order to assure quality performance.    
The only downside is the occasional call from a local or state politician during elections season, which usually comes in around midnight or 1 a.m. here in Switzerland.      
Incidentally, you can also have a pretty good time telling a US sales caller that you are interested in carpet cleaning or an alarm system, giving them a four-digit postal code and seeing what they say.

Their 9chf monthly charge will buy you an hour of calls to Swiss mobiles on Voipcheap. Quite a head start! The Gigaset 610ip I have is a newer version of the phone Switzernet are promoting (see Marie_89's post). It is a little more expensive around 95chf. I have been using voipcheap since 2005. Call quality has been excellent. I also have a SIP client on my iphone, and often dial out on that if I am within range of any good wlan connection, say at friends etc.    
The Gigaset 610ip lets you plug in a land line as well as the net cable, and the stylish handset will answer calls from either the land line or any of your internet phones. Outgoing calls can be programmed to use any internet account or land line based on dialed number. It also displays the callers name for incoming calls if they are listed in the Swiss telephone book!

They post out the equipment to you which (in my case) arrived before my "live" date. If however work needs to be done to install a cable or even to activate a dormant cable you would need to harass them a bit or organise an engineer/electrician yourself (though when we did it we weren't charged for the engineer).

Was just going to warn you about that.  If you use a power strip it should NOT have any surge protection.  You just wants something that just gives you more sockets. I got mine in Lowes back home for like $4-5 for 5 outlets.

Another thread,

There are 3 physical mobile networks in Switzerland, Swisscom, Sunrise and Orange.    
The "Mobile Country Code", or MCC for Switzerland is 228. All 3 Swiss operators have this. The "Mobile Network Code", or MNC, is a unique number inside of the country.   
Here's the 3 for Switerland:   Operator---MCC---MNC  Swisscom 228 01 Sunrise 228 02 Orange 228 03     If you can put your phone into some kind of "field-test" mode, you can usually see this info, otherwise you need an app installed. For Android phones, you can download "Cellumap"  from the Android Market (free). There's probably something similar for iPhone as well.   
Here's a screenshot from Cellumap, you can see from the MCC-MNC of 228-01 that this phone is on the Swisscom network. You can also see the operator name. But if this phone was for example on M-Budget, it may show the name as "M-Budget Mobile", because that's what's read from the SIM card, but the MCC-MNC is taken from the radio, and that would still show 228-01 because M-Budget is a MVNO ("Virtual Operator") using the Swisscom physical network.       
Respectively, Coop-Mobile should show MCC-MNC 228-03 because they are using the Orange network. Aldi Mobile and Lebara should show 228-02 because they are using the Sunrise network.   
*edit*   
oops, you are trying to find out what network   number is on. Oh, what i wrote is valid for your phone, mainly for people using MVNO's (like Coop Mobile).

Hello  all, sorry first post might be another "problem" with the swiss way of doing things, but im fresh out of options.   
I moved to a new house in Lausanne last year in Aug after living in a small town outside Lausanne.  
i run a busy company both here in switzerland and Denmark and as an owner i run through all invoices and pay them.  After about 8 to 9 month i by accident actually looked at my invoice from the energy company and see that in between the lines they have added something called "multimedia ". 
i does not say what it is or what its for , so since im a paying client with Swisscom and has been happily since i arrived i called up Romande who told me outright that since i paid the first invoice it was considered that i had agreed to this service. it seems that its a  broadban for internet and tv ( i use swisscom bluewintv and pay for this along side used to use cablecom for tv ) i told them that i had never been asked or even told that this existed ( not by a salesperson, letter, notifications or anything  by them, the company i rent the house from or the owner of the house, but they did not care.  I then got really upset since in my world this is borderline fraud. they promised they would get back to me. 
now almost 3 months later i still have not heard anything from them except for the regular invoices which i of course want to pay, but by doing so im actaully paying for the "multimedia" and thereby accepting the fraud. they are only writting me in French despite i have told them via phone and emails on 5 occations i only speak English and German.   
anyone else in this forum who has encountered this problem before and got it solved ?  Also  im suspecting they are just trying to get some free money from all foreigners whos companies pay their bills this way and therefor most often does not question this.  All my nabours who are swiss french and people i work with who are also swiss are totally agreeing with me here, but its like ramming your head against a concrete block to get theese people to admit fraud, cheating and other nasty tricks.   
i would be greatfull for any advise and input.   
AND yes i could have gone through the first invoice when i received it but paying around 50 to 60 invoices per week made me just naivly think that the power company would only charge me for electricty and nothing else. 
ask yourself how many of you who will go through your reciept from COOP each time you shop in the weekend, and if you did not and they charged you 40 CHF for sunshine in Switzerland and would do so in the future  just because you paid it the first time  and didnt complain      
Best regards

Oh, and you don't _need_ to pay an increased subscription - many channels (i.e. the normally free ones, BBC, CH4 etc.) are available on their HD broadcasts without a new subscription.

post:
Here's an interesting explanation about SIM-locks.      
Short answer: the phone can either be locked to the general network "Network Lock" (eg. Swisscom, Sunrise, Orange), in which case all SIM cards using that network (including resellers) can be used with the phone......    
...or, the phone can be locked more narrowly to a "Service Provider" (or "Subnetwork Lock"), in which case you can only use the phone with the service provider who sold the phone (eg. a Lebara phone will only work with a LeBara SIM card and not a Sunrise SIM)   
So, generally speaking, it depends on how the phone was locked, it's maybe a 50/50 chance it will work with a reseller SIM card. I think older phones maybe were locked with the general "network lock", but maybe newer phones are using the narrower "service provider" lock (just guessing). Unfortunately there is no way to know how the phone was locked without actually trying another SIM card and finding out.   
PS- MCC for Switzerland is 228. The MNC for Swisscom is 01, Sunrise 02 and Orange 03. That's the 3 physical networks, so a "Network Lock" will only look for that. As for "Subsets", it's something related to your subscription/SIM card.

In Europe the 3G networks are very fast and reliable, so the network operators are not in much of a rush to roll out 4G. In the US, Verizon and Sprint's "3G" is actually a souped-up 2G (EVDO) that can never go over 3Mbps. So they are in more of a rush to get 4G out.    
AT&T's 3G (HSPA) network has good speeds, and they could probably milk that a while longer before deploying 4G, but if they want to "keep up with the Jones'" they'll have to get out 4G sooner than they expected.

Hi,    
If you have swiss SIM card (i.e. Sunrise, Orange, Lycamobile), and you are in Switzerland, then the recipient of the call won't pay anything regardless of the fact where the orginator of the call is.    
If you   a call, while in Switzerland, then you do NOT pay.      
However: note that you need to explain to your relatives that: 
- if they recieve calls to their US number, then they will pay so-called "roaming charge"    for receiving calls 
- if your relatives   the call from their US number to their CH number, then they will pay   to their US number subscription.   The originator of the call (if in US) will pay only US->US call, though.    
Cheers!

I'm in the same boat having taken an Orange iPhone account in Feb of last year after the sales droid assured me up and down that, should I leave the country, that there wouldn't be a termination fee. Posts here also suggested that this was correct.   
I went to cancel my contract 2 weeks ago and...bam, 800 CHF said the dude at the Orange office. Mobile operators are mobsters on any continent and, forever more, I will buy an untethered phone and a pay as you go SIM.   
However, we both may be in luck as though I don't want to leave with a debt hanging over me, I also absolutely refuse to pay an 800CHF extortion fee.   
See   and click on "useful tips" where you will find the following text;   
"i am leaving Switzerland and need to cancel my subscription, how do I do it? 
You're currently an Orange customer but getting ready for adventures outside Switzerland? No problem. You'll simply need to inform us (by calling Customer Care free on 0800 700 700) that you want to cancel your subscription and provide us with a document from your community confirming that you are leaving the country.    
If you have been with us for less than 6 months or have benefited from a handset offer recently, you may have to pay a penalty fee."   
We have legal insurance and, so, if they try to stick it to us tomorrow, I will just pursue it legally as a) I was lied to at the point of sale and b) their FAQ is ambiguous but also leads me to believe that I can cancel the contract after 6 months without penalty.   
In contrast, Swisscom was a breeze and immediately changed to a pay as you go scheme for my husband's phone. Of course, their service sucked balls outside of Switzerland but...I guess you can't have it all.   
I really hope there's a circle in Dante's hell for Mobile Operators. AT&T first into the fire. Never again will I trust these folks.    
Best advice to those new to CH without an absolute certainty that they'll be around for more than a year - pay up front for the phone and get a pay as you go plan. Much less hassle.

There is of course the subtle difference between progressive and interlaced. BBC is 1080i.   
If you only count pixels HD Suisse (720x1280=921600) shows more of them per frame than BBC HD (1080/2*1440=777600).   
They would argue 720p will give you better image quality. I disagree as they use cameras with 1080 lines sensors and the displays at home have 1080 lines of resolution, the hardware was not built for 720p.   
It was all meant very well but is very much nonsense in reality but I think they will be too proud to admit to that.

Fust is the only company that I've dealt with that takes old appliances at time of delivery. But you pay for this service twice - firstly their prices, and secondly the delivery itself.

Your TV reception options, in many places in Switzerland:     
Satellite (DVB-S), free and/or pay 
Terrestrial (DVB-T), over the air, free 
Cable (DVB-C), basic fee for analog, DVB-C is pay 
VDSL, Swisscom TV, pay 
VDSL, Sunrise TV, pay     
upc cablecom (cable) 
Swisscom (VDSL) 
Sunrise (VDSL) 
Various (satellite) (not all are valid for CH)   
Quantity of channels received vary hugely by Reception Technology and Pay Providers.   
It all boils down to what you want....

I know there is no bandwidth limitation imposed by Cablecom, I am more interested in knowing just out of my own curiosity. I'm a "techie-type" with a large home network, that has just about everything integrated (VOIP phones, NAS, TV, media-streamer, etc), and I'm interested to see any sudden increase in internet bandwidth, so it could give me a heads up if one of the devices is not acting correctly, or if something else is wrong. For example, if for several months I am using 2GB per month, then suddenly one month it's 20GB, then I will see something looks wrong and investigate why the sudden increase.   
I do have a DD-WRT router in my home network, and there is a way with rflow to monitor data-traffic of each networked device, however it does it in kind of a messy way (needs an external PC running mSQL to stay on), and counts internal traffic also (ie: no way to differentiate traffic staying inside my network, or traffic going external).    
So, in short, I just want to see what my monthly internet data usage is. Pretty simple request, that seems doesn't have a simple answer

You need to be able to see your box's signal test screen so you can see what signal strength you're getting and when the lock says OK.

Hi Surfpowder,      
In response to your comments:   
I noticed a problem with my photo gallery the day before when it kept closing when I was trying to look at the album. Unfortunately I did not take the time to check it out and fix it.   
I changed the password immediately and (hopefully) took all the steps necesary. I am now resetting the phone to factory setting. I have only used the Android market - for freebees I thought were ok choosing those with the most stars.    
I disconnected the yahoo app immediately as well. When I re-install I will use the "SSL" option - good idea.    
As for passwords: I have always used different ones as you suggested - and clean out the cache after Ebanking.    
We use a firewall on our closed system here at home for the 6 computers we use.    
Not only are security measures the best prevention, but to also try to think one step ahead. We have to renew our software in a week. The security gap was on my phone was discussed 1 day before the attack. sigh....

It all boils down to the quality of the compenents.  In CD/DVD/BD players There are lots of moving parts, lenses etc.. that get the data off the disc itself, then there is the components used to handle this data, plus Error corrections etc...  Quality will depend on number 'bits' etc.. For CD's the digital information is converted to analogue etc..  On top of this is the quality of the power supply and if different component groups share the same power supply or have separate ones (to avoid interferance etc...)..   
I suggest some google searches on these topics.

you just need a universal LNB, there isnt a specific "sky" LNB.   
90cm is more than enough, i have frinds with the original sky mini dish 45cm and its ok except in bad weather. With a properly aligned 80 cm dish in all but the most extreme weather, its perfect.   
I would suggest buying a simple needle/scale type strength meter as the built in guage on the sky box has a major time delay and is heavily damped so it will take you ages.   
Also remember to rotate the LNB to the correct angle as that will make a massive difference in signal strength.   
Out landlord complained about the balcony dish also - no one else with a dish recieved a complaint (those nasty auslanders again!)  so i put a section of Balkonschutz/Balkonverkleidung  on the railing of the balcony so the dish can not be seen from the road. The material is grey so blends in perfectly with the building.  Everyone is happy now.

post:
This is from ricksteves.com a travel writer which is pretty much what I thought.  Get a prepaid SIM card for each country you are in to make calls in that country.     
Rates: If you're calling from the SIM card's home country, you'll generally pay around 10 to 20 cents per minute for domestic calls to fixed lines, and nothing to receive calls. (Calls to mobile phones tend to be more expensive.) Calling the US can cost $1 per minute or more — but using an international phone card with your mobile phone can bring that cost down to pennies.   
A SIM card works most affordably in the country where you buy it. If you roam with the SIM card in another country, call prices go up, and you pay to receive incoming calls. If your SIM card is from a European Union (EU) country, fees are regulated when roaming within the EU: You'll pay no more than about 55 cents per minute to make calls or 21 cents per minute to receive calls. If your SIM card is from a non-EU country — or if you're traveling in one — roaming fees can be much higher. If you'll be making a lot of calls, it can be cheaper to buy a new SIM card for that country.   
Remember to store your phone numbers in the phone itself, rather than on the SIM card — or you'll lose access to them when you switch SIMs. When storing phone numbers, include the plus (+) sign and the country code so your calls will go through, regardless of where you're calling from.

post:
It won't be easy to get an iPhone without a credit history here. I'd personally buy the phone unlocked directly from Apple (or, if it doesn't have to be an iPhone, go for the new HTC Desire HD that's going to be released in October - definitely the much better phone). 
Waiting time for the iPhone is about 3-9 weeks in Switzerland at the moment.    
As for the provider: in my opinion, Orange is the worst of the three Swiss providers. They have (by far) the worst coverage, they don't have EDGE (which sucks big time if you have a smartphone - once you leave their measly 3G coverage area, you'll be looking at 9.6-56k download speeds. An average website takes about 2-4 minutes to load at that speed) and their customer service is sub-par. There's only one factor that makes a lot of people here choose Orange: they offer calls abroad at local rates. So if you will be calling overseas all the time from your cell-phone, you could consider them.    
Otherwise, go for Sunrise - they're way cheaper and have a vastly better network - much better 3G network and EDGE where there's no 3G. Unlimited calling to Swiss networks and unlimited data (speed reduced after reaching 2gb / month) costs 105 Fr.  Unlimited texts cost an additional 19 Fr.  - but who needs texts if you have push e-mail on your phone.    
The most expensive of the providers is Swisscom. They used to have the best network. Nowadays, they are suffering from network-congestion a lot  because they have the most customers. Their network is generally slower than Sunrise's. They have the best customer service, though.
The stick. You can even buy the prepaid ones in Migros or Coop. They will work just fine.

You're most welcome!   
I considered that plan as well, but I blew through the 2GB/month limit on Swisscom in two days (hence my trying out the cheaper, somewhat slower, but not-limited Sunrise). Lesson learned: if a computer has been offline for months due to being moved, doing Windows Updates on mobile broadband can be bad.    
In general, my use for mobile broadband is intermittent (though bandwidth-heavy): a backup connection in case my wired connection is down, and also for connecting when away from the apartment or university, so the prepaid plans that charge only on the days one uses the service made a lot of sense for me. Naturally, your mileage may vary.

Frankly, the media companies here are dominated by people who don't only speak German, they mostly also hold an M.A. in German, sociology, media studies - all of which are massively language-oriented. I minored in media studies myself and have yet to find a Swiss media company where English (or anything except for German, French and / or Italian) is spoken. Most companies look for people who speak at least two of the official languages.    
Also, the Swiss media landscape is extremely limited - outside of public TV and radio plus about 2-3 bigger newspapers, there's absolutely nothing. Most areas in Switzerland don't have any media companies at all but are instead served by larger corporations in the bigger cities. There are close to ZERO media jobs available in Switzerland and the number has been on the decline for 15 years or so.   
Apart from that, you'll find it very difficult to obtain a work permit here if you don't have a Swiss or EU passport.    
Sorry to say this so bluntly: you'll either have to get C2 (fluency)-level German or you'll be struggling massively to find anything.   
Peter

M Budget contracts offer good prices in Switzerland (on the Swisscom network- which I can also get at home), but once you enter the French network, you pay roaming charges which are extortionate.   
I came across a company called Transnatel, which offers calls and texts specifically for cross-border workers, whereby you get both a French and Swiss number and can call at local rates, but they don't seem to offer data packages.

post:
These services are not backup services, they are remote storage. 
Backup services will have a universal client that actually backs up data , and stores it in generational format so that file versioning is achieved.   
Be clear about your requirements, do you need an off site copy of local storage , or the ability to restore to a point in time, any specific file, or do you need synchronisation of remote storage between clients , or do you need to move off local storage onto cloud storage ? Many options are available.   
For Security and Professionalism, I would recommend that you consider a Virtual Private Server, under your full control, preferably with mirrored contingency/backup data centers. This would allow you to use rsynch and rcopy commands to copy local files to your remote server, if you get a VPN sorted, you can have the server present it's remote storage as a local drive on the PC and the PC users can use native backup tools that the clients are familiar with.   
Going with a VPS gives you full control, n-way mirroring , n-way synching, verifiable encryption (encrypt before you send and store on an alien server) etc.  
The server can also be used for mail/web/ftp/torrent purposes.    
The down side ? 50CHF a month instead of 5CHF a month.   
How much is your data worth ? Google VPS and Europe and take your pick.

Thank you all for helping me sort this out.   
I got to the bottom of it all eventually, and am liable for the connection fee on top of the subscription fee.    
If anyone reading this is thinking of subscribing to cablecom, its definitely worth checking with cablecom and your landlord who is liable for this.  My contract says my Nebenkosten covers the connection, but apparently, after the contracts were drawn up, the property owners agreed with cablecom that the tenants would pay..... I know that this is a bit fishy in itself, so I will be requesting a full breakdown of the Nebenkosten "costs" and any refund due.   
Oh, and the small costs totalling about 5chf on my subscription bill....well, these are fees for the connection for the first day of connection.  Apparently cablecom have to wait 24 hours before enabling the subscription proper, so charge on a daily basis for this.  This has been refunded.

post:
The short answer is that the MacBook itself will be able to receive and transfer data as fast as your network/internet connection can provide it.  If you consider the internet connection as something like:   
internet -> ISP (the company, e.g. CableCom that provides your internet service) -> modem in your house -> your MacBook -> data processed and on your screen   
Then by far the slowest part of that chain will be the ISP -> modem link.  All the other components will be able to run far faster.  As technology improves, each of these steps gets faster, but the relative difference remains because they are all getting faster.  Even a 5+ year old computer and home network should be fast enough to deal with data from today's fastest home internet connections, so it is likely that your MacBook will be fast enough for you for the foreseeable future.  I have a 2008 MacBook base model, and it has no trouble keeping up with the speed that CableCom can get data to my flat, so a 2011 model should be more than good enough.

I don't have any online logins that require me to change passwords. Some sites don't accept punctuation, strangely enough, so I also have another version of my phrase or name in case.

The only problem with stepdown transformers is they seem to use a lot of power when plugged in, even if the appliances are not running. I brought my wifi router US phone and Vonage modem from the US, and plugged them into 3 separate step down transformers.    
After speaking with my neighbors, we determined that my power bills were a LOT higher than theirs, with somewhat similar usage patterns. The power company actually came out to take some measurements and determined that my stepdown transformers were probably costing me about 40% extra per year.  I was surprised and skeptical, but it seems that they were right. I could have bought a wifi router and phone here and gone with just one transformer and would have saved plenty of money. Maybe i had bad transformers, but they seem to always be a fairly warm, so I figure that means they are consuming power.

I've got both, well not   rather  , a cable tv provider from Zug.         is recording menu and options. For example you can log onto Swisscom's website and set your box to record any program you wish from anywhere in the world. Not something someone would need every day but there has been a few times I was at work and remembered I forgot to set it to record a show I wanted to watch so I just logged on from work and did it remotely. In addition to being able to edit the recording times you can also program the channels via the Internet as well (add, remove or rearrange channels). I set up the whole list of channels and all my preferences via my computer instead of the box.   
Very stable system (see disadvantages cable tv)      Reception, from day 1 my Swisscom TV reception has never equalled my cable tv provider's quality. The first day Swisscom announced they were making TV available I ordered it, those early days (first year) were horrible. Often the sound didn't match up with the picture. They worked it out finally but it required me to abandon ISDN and go back to analog phone service. Analog allowed me to use a faster DSL which gave me better tv quality. As an incentive to switch to analog Swisscom was nice enough to pay me CHF 250.- for new phones and did the conversion (technician came to my place for the install) free of charge.   
Channels that are broadcasting in two languages always revert back to the first sound track when changing channels. If you like to channel surf that means constantly having to hit the language selection button to see if the channel in question is broadcasting in English (very annoying).           External hard drives..!! I've got a 1 TB drive hooked up to my recorder and can record hundreds of hours of programing, many times more than the Swisscom TV achieve. Plus if you absolutely don't want to erase the drive you can always go out and buy a new one.    
More HD channels.      having to hit the language button to see if a program is broadcasting in English. Once you've set the system preferences to English you will have   every time you switch to a channel that is broadcasting a program in English..!! (My most loved advantage of cable tv over Swisscom).      System crashing/rebooting. Sometimes clicking something in the menu or changing channels would cause the system to crash and reboot, very annoying in the beginning but they seem to have most of the bugs worked out. It still crashes from time to time but at least now it's only once every month or two.       : To put it in a nutshell, phone and cable providers do best what they were designed to do (Swisscom=phones, cable TV=television). Sure they've tweaked their technologies to included each other's services but when you get right down to it, a phone company still serves the best phone service and a cable tv company, the best tv reception.

Agreed. My husband used to have Orange, and he didn't have reception half of the time. Sometime later, he talked to his company, who agreed to pay his mobile bill (on-call work). He just had to cancel Orange and get the number transferred to the provider they used. Not so simple!   
First of all, Orange said it was ok to transfer, but the new provider kept sending us letters that the transfer had been refused. This went on for months. All of a sudden, the people at Orange were claiming he had to pay the next bill. Well, after a few months of back and forth, we find out they thought he owed a bill from 2 years before. He talked to them, and they said, "oops, no, you don't have to pay. We'll cancel your contract." He asked if he had   fee to pay and the answer was a no. Number was transferred, and we thought we had heard the end of it.   
Oh, no. A month or so later, we get a bill from a collection agency (on behalf of Orange) for something like 300 CHF, threatening us to pay within x days or else! Now, we had never received any bill of the sort from Orange (so how had it been escalated to a collection agency for failure to pay?), and they had assured us there was absolutely nothing to pay in bills, cancelation, etc. Nice.   
So, never again will we consider Orange. It was such a nightmare. Though I have no idea if the others are better.   
Anyway, good luck. I hope your experience is better than ours was.

thread: Configuring my Cablecom Router with a MAC

post:
In Zurich upc cablecom have the fastest network, the lowest prices, and pretty good service. Plus loads of forum members here online that can help, should you need it.   
You'll be up and running within 48hrs after ordering online.   
Tips: 
Always use GigE networks inside your house if going for more than 50Mbit/s internet speed.   
Use cabled networks whereever you can (although the new upc cablecom modems have wifi built in), simply because cable is reliable, always on, and much faster than wifi.   
I have both, but WiFi is a backup if the cabled connection fails

Firstly: use a wire connection with cat5e or cat6 cables on GigE ports and monitor that connection. If the wired connection is fine, it means the WLAN is dodgy. If WLAN dodgy, follow usual WLAN diagnosis (switch of other devices, move cordless phones away, etc)   
Note that you cannot get 100Mbit/s throughput on a 100Mbit/s port. To measure 100Mbit/s throughput, everything must use GigE ports and cat5e or cat6 cabling. 
On a 100Mbit/s port, you'd be lucky to get more than 75 Mbit/s throughput. 
The Thomspon modem has GigE ports. Your new Ethernet card hopefully should as well. Make sure the connecting cable is cat5e or cat6 (written on the cable).   
Secondly: 100M fiberpower uses multiple bundled DOCSIS upstream and downstream channels. This greater demand on available channels means you are more likely to suffer problems if the cabling from the local node to your apartment wall socket is not perfect. The types of problems and types of interference that can exist are extensive and numerous. Right down to: an innocent neighbour may have a cable problem, which injects interference into the cable network, which interferes with exactly your wanted DOCSIS signal. I went to a course once where all this was explained and demonstrated - it is amazing the types of problems that can occur.   
So history shows that 90% of all problems exist in the subscriber's own   building.   
So my guess is (in order of likeliness) 
a) old, incapable wiring in the building/apartment 
b) old wall sockets 
c) damaged cable modem cable to wall socket 
d) defective cable modem 
e) wrong ethernet cable 
f) wifi interference (if using wifi)   
A process of elimination will quickly have you sorted.   
Don't play with modem firmware, the cable modem will have specific firmware loaded by the network operator, which will be a known good version   
Good luck!

post:
To be honest the "junction box in the street" is a very wide approximation of the situation. 
In fact the "raccordement" thing they try to sell you is when they can't connect your line to the one going to your flat.   
Ex: Bob previous tenant had phone 022123456. The line was "connected" so even when he left they simply switched off the service. But the lines are still connected.   
In your case they don't know what line will go to your flat, and try to make you pay.   
But to connect the line they will give you a "technical reference" (such as 55 or whatever specific). You simply need to go into the building room with all the cables for everyone.   
They will be displayed the 55 there. Now the trick is to find out which one is going to your flat.   
Guess what probably all your neighboors have a phone/internet already connected so your's is the unconnected one.   
To actually test its deadly simple: take a phone and connect it on your landline plug, in your flat.   
Take that cable from 55 and simply make it touch the empty socket you suspect's the one going to your flat. 
Keep the contact or screw it (it's all simple to do there's everything). Ring your landline number. ask a mate to stay home and listen. 
 If it rings on your landline, bingo you found the empty cable you need to connect. If not ring, try to make it touch to another empty socket, ring again.   
Bingo you saved 180chf. for a few minutes guess work.

The key point to be aware of is that you'll struggle to find a "rolling contract" of the type I suspect you're thinking of in Switzerland, as in a "monthly rolling contract". They are typically 12- or 24-month contracts, and if not cancelled in time roll into another 12 or more month contract.    
For a six-month stay, you should really opt for prepaid, i.e. pay-as-you-go. As others have said, details and prices are being discussed elsewhere on the forum.

post: Yes the limitation of a non-3G connection is that it can't support  simultaneous voice and data. (It's a limitation of the chip design in the phone It only has one receiver  and that will never change.). This is the same as CDMA in the USA. If the phone starts a calls when there is an active data connection then the phone can decide to bump the data connection and let the voice call through. But if the call is incoming then the network must decide to bump the data connection. With both Orange and Sunrise in CH this is not happening. And given the rubbish state of both carriers 3G networks, this amounts to huge amount of missed calls when you phone drops to the 2G network....

Your assumption is correct: to record a TV program, you must use a recorder. That is a basic prerequisite for recording TV programs.   
The recorder can be either built into the TV (check if your TV has a built-in recorder, some do) or a separate external device.   
The external recorder can be a recorder of your own choice, chosen to integrate into your TV setup according to your needs and desires and price bracket.   
How you connect your recorder depends on the connection capabilities of your TV system.

Hmm, I would say some traffic prioritisations going on.    
Internet speed is rarely anything to do with how new/fast/shiny the computer is. Common misconception. Yes if you clog it up with junk it will have an affect, but in 20 years of working/dealing with IT I've seen maybe x3 occasions of where the PC is at fault. Usually virus related.   
Saying this I have seen poor DNS setups on the ISP end this can cause internet dropouts.

Our Cablecom Digital TV picture quality has degraded quite badly over the last few days in 8008. Has anyone else started getting poor picture quality ?   
Have done the basic checks. Reset the boxes, checked cable connections , reseated everything etc. DVD playback is fine and TV is quite new so I do not suspect the TV to be at fault.

i signed up for swisscom-TV last January, one month later I went to the swisscom shop to terminate the contract (within the trial period), and return the equipment at the same time.   
Last February I still received a TV bill. I inquired the shop and got informed that I still need to pay it for the whole year, as that is the minimum duration of the contract. Afterwards I can get my money back. OK, I continued my payment without arguing.    
Now it has been one year and is the time to collect the money. I inquired again and was told that I will be refunded monthly by subtracting the overcharge from my bill, since I have other service from swisscom. In fact I am thinking of changing a provider now, but apparently I still have to be bonded with swisscom for a while, if I want my money back.   
I am not sure if this is a typical case or just a mishandling on me. Just want to recommend a second thought to those who are considering to give swisscom-TV a try.

So in case anyone ever finds themselves in the same situation - it's possible to buy additional Swisscom credit online using your credit card.       
It's pretty easy - took about half an hour from the time I bought credit to the time I got a text back from Swisscom saying they'd unblocked my account.   
Mods, you can lock this one up.

The new provider can cancel you, but you usually have to fill in a form to send off to your old provider at the time of signing the new contract.   
You still need to adhere to your old provider's contract termination clause and have all your bills paid before the new provider can port your number over.

post:
Reason is that it is supposed to act like your office line or something. So your company can have it configured so you dial short numbers like office extension numbers from your mobile. With mine I can also dial a zero first as if it was 0 for an outside line. For example if I wanna dial a Zurich nmber I'd dial 0044 xxx xx xx. For international calls like calling France it'd be 00033 xx xx xx xx etc.   
Putting the international code using the + format just ensures that you are actually dialling that telephone number instead of a local CMN number.   
Maybe there's some more information on Swisscom's website.

When the power supply for my Acer Aspire 1640 notebook began to give trouble, I bought a 90 watt 'Notebook Power Adapter' for 59 CHF 
from PC-Hai in Zürich. It can be used for a variety of different makes of notebook by means of 10 different connectors, 4 of which are specifically for Dell. It works fine with my Acer. Fortunately it appears that all notebooks require the same 19 volt power. There is also another model which can supply 120 watts, but costs over 100 CHF.

Yes it is via the coxial/high def cable. No need for your telephone jack with Cablecom. 
You have a jack on your wall with 2 regular outputs and one narrow. The narrow one is for cable internet. The digital phone connection is then connected to your router. The two other outputs on the wall are then for TV and radio.

QRok Annonces is offering mobile phone services for Switzerland.   
Founded in 2010 in Toulouse, Qroktag is a company specialized in developing mobile solutions. Qroktag creates and develops new mobile applications to meet the demands of individuals and professionals looking for new services and new uses.       
Qrok Ads is a new service FACEBOOK using QR Codes ( ). 
A French/Swiss service entirely free of ads (business & individual) with automatic generation of QR Code for each ad.   
Each QR Code provides on his mobile, after scanning, photo, YouTube video to see a related announcement, the geolocation of your property. Contact the advertiser and the ability to save this property in your bag scan!   
The Facebook app lets you share your ads on the network with your friends ...       
QRok Card ( ) lets you build very easy to share or interactive postcards.   
1 - You choose a photo on your computer 
2 - You choose your message (text, link to video) 
3 - You call (zoom, color & print ,....) share your home on your printer 
4 - You know by sending your mail, 
5 - The caller receives the share & can see your multimedia message on his mobile.   
This service is completely free.

Well, I hope you will get it sorted out...   
Make sure you find someone reasonable who will pick up the phone in Justitia and they will ask you to write your side of the story. Then try to get evidence from Orange in form of history of your account.   
I dealt with Justitia lately over unpaid UPS bill which they mistakenly billed me twice and even despite my intervention with the UPS themselves, agent still insisted I must pay it. After exchange of few emails, there was silence and I thought the whole matter was settled. Not until debt collecting agency sent me the letter.   
I stayed calm, picked up a phone and called Justitia and explained to them the whole thing about mistake being made in English. The lady on the other side was very helpful and asked me to write my "opinion" i.e. side of the story.   
All I can say try to track it down to detail, explain what happened and only can hope that eventually you will get it right.
