post:
I am one of the first FON subscribers in Spain (where the idea was generated). There, although the idea is/was very cool, not many people use it. I've had a hotspot for about 6-7 years now and I think noone has connected to it yet... And I live quite near a hotel, in a town center of a turistic area. Not many neighbours, though.   
However, I used FON connections in different countries such as the UK, Japan and Korea, but you can't really go somewhere and think you'll have internet in these places.   
You can only use remote FONs without paying if you're sharing your current connection for free (same for others).   
Anyway, the router is a good deal for the price and it seem to be growing in many places (in some countries they have agreements with big public Wireless providers, which can be an advantage).   
Google about it and take your pick.

Hi folks,   
does anyone know what this message from Swisscom means? 
On another forum we're sending mails to our users and since about 1 week this mail gets regularly sent to us:   
** English **
This is an automated message. Please do not reply.
The account you tried to reach has been temporarily disabled. 
** Deutsch **
Dies ist eine automatisch generierte Nachricht. Bitte antworten Sie nicht auf dieses Mail.
Die Mail-Adresse, die sie angeschrieben haben, wurde vorübergehend gesperrt. 
** Français **
Ceci est un message généré automatiquement. Merci de ne pas répondre à ce message.
L'adresse email que vous avez adressé a été désactivée temporairement. 
** Italiano **
Questo è un messaggio generato automaticamaente. Si prega di non rispondere a questo messaggio.
L'indirizzo email da lei indirizzato è stato disattivato temporaneamente.     
The language is pretty clear to me - however I (we) do not understand what kind of error is associated with this message. 
Usually one receives something like:     Final-Recipient: MrMrsJohnJoe@whatever.dot
Action: failed
Status: 5.2.2
X-Display-Name: Mr and Mrs John Joe   
Thank you for any helpful ideas...   
Paul

Apparently it depends on which type and make of box you have. In my case (a grey mediabox recorder), I had to flip open the flap on the front left of the box and hold down two buttons at the same time. I think it was a green (or a red?) button plus the left arrow.     : I would not recommend doing this on your own. Give Cablecom a call so they can talk you through it.

I am fairly certain that my Sky payments were declined in 2006 after I reported my card lost. They shut down my service at least one month after the card change and did not resume service until I gave them the new card number. My original contract started in 2004 and was eventually terminated in 2007.

Do not put up with this.  I had the exact same problem (zurich) - did not fix itself within about 3 weeks.  I called them up and arranged to replace the box - upgraded to the HD box, which even on the normal channels seems to give a clearer picture and more reliable operation, although certainly not fault-free.

You should first check on the cablecom website if you have a cablecom connection in the building or not.   
I think for cablecom you only need a cable socket in the wall. Usually this is in the hall. Cablecom provides you a modem where there is a internet phone port. There you connect the phone to work. There are no cablecon phone socket on the wall as such.
Never any problem for me (except in the underground garage!) and no changes recently. Perhaps it's the cold or wrong type of snow?

This will depend upon what you mean by will it work.    
Sony are a little bit funny with their TVs and if you get the long model number you will see that it is something like KDL-40W4000U. The last letter relates to the region the TV is designed for, where U is the UK and and E would be Europe. The only difference between the two is that a European TV has a cable decoder in there, the UK one does not.   
Therefore, if you want to plug TV directly into your cable socket in the wall of your apartment it is not going to work.    
As mentioned by the other posters, there are ways to make the TV work. Basically if you have any set top box, be that sky, freeview, cablecom, or who ever else is providing the service in your area, these will connect to the TV through a scart or HDMI cable, all of which will work.    
The basic analogue cable connections are providing fewer and fewer channels as they push digital tv, which requires a set top box, and as mentioned cablecom's 6,- a month offering is pretty good.    
So there should be no problem bringing over the TV, just don't plug it directly into the cable outlet in the wall.

post:
I was going to cancel my Swisscom Mobile Unlimited package and go for a Sunrise or Orange data stick. After reviewing this extensively, I ended up sticking with Swisscom. Why?   
- The Sunrise network SUCKS. The 3G coverage is about 1/5 of that of Swisscom - just check out the network coverage maps 
- Orange doesn't have EDGE. Outside their (minimalistic) 3G network, the data stick becomes unusable. 
- With Swisscom, you can use WiFi networks all over the place - it's included in your data flat package. The other providers don't offer WiFi.    
Waiting for the merger to happen doesn't make too much sense. 1st of all it'll take until May until the anti-trust agency will decide whether they can merge at all. And if they can, it'll be another year or so until the networks are interconnected. By then, my contract will have run out and I can re-evaluated.   
And last but not least: the price difference between Swisscom's top-notch network and the ridiculously bad coverage of Sunrise and Orange is a mere 10 Fr. per month. Not worth the trouble, if you ask me. I'm paying 59 Fr. now for the data flat + free WiFi all over the country, including on trains etc.
Thanks to Polorise and tomcat, I should be radiating myself silly with a 9700 from tomorrow.  Hazah!

There is a very small (and I mean small) chance, that you can dispute it.   
For the AGB's to be valid in German law, there are a few conditions that must be met.   
1: "Widerrufsbelehrung" must be visible in the AGB's, so that you can not miss it when you scroll over the text. It is in fact not in the AGB itself but a seperate point right next to the AGB's, and the "Widerrufsbelehrung itself is framed and extra big headline, so I doubt, that it will be valid, but it may be worth a try.       
Das OLG Frankfurt a.M. hat darauf hingewiesen, dass eine   in Allgemeine Geschäftsbedingungen nur dann eingebettet werden kann, wenn dies in der gesetzlich geforderten hervorgehobenen und deutlich gestalteten Form erfolgt. Die von der Antragsgegnerin verwendete Widerrufsbelehrung sei, neben einer unzureichenden Link-Kennzeichnung, zu beanstanden, weil sie zu unauffällig in die Allgemeinen Geschäftsbedingungen eingebettet sei.   
A rough Translation:     
2: For the AGB's to be valid, there must be an option to download and save them, and that is missing. That is probably your better chance to dispute it.   
I have looked it up before and succesfully disputed an online subscription 1 year ago, but can not find the link anymore. I am pretty sure, it was somewhere on this webpage though:        
Doc.   
Edit: added a rough translation of the german part. German legal language is difficult to translate, but hope it is reasonably understandable.

post:
I live in a four storey house and due to all the reinforced concrete, I've difficulty getting a signal one story up or down from the wireless router!  ( Wireless technology seems to have been designed for the US market rather than the Swiss - US houses have less RF absorbing materials   ).     
The solution I've gone for is networking over the power lines.  The router is connected via standard network cabling to a power network adaptor.  On the other floors, we connect the computers to additional power network adaptors.  It works fine, and it was cheaper and more reliable than using a repeater/booster.   
In your case, set up a receiver at the sweet point, and then convert to a network over power from there.  Network adaptors can usually be set to use decent encryption, so your network traffic is secure.

If it helps... a bit of history...   
BBC1, BBC2, ITV1, Channel 4, Channel 5 are the original terrestrial channels in the UK (i.e. available via normal antenna). The rest like BBC3-4, ITV2-4, More 4, etc. have always been digital channels (i.e. available only via cable/satellite/digital terrestrial).   
The original terrestrial channels are the "prime" channels of the respective companies and normally are the channels that broadcast the news for/up to date shows, etc. The digital destined channels generally show repeats of shows, specific series, genres, etc.

How old is this TV?  I ask because the nominal native resolutions are now 720 and 1080.  768 is usually a monitor for computer.   
As far as contrast ratios of over 3000 they aren't real.  The 100,000:1 numbers you get are derived by comparing the maximum brightness output to the minimum brightness output.  Basically full on versus full off.  This isn't how monitors work so it isn't relevant and if you watch modern display devices at full contrast with auto iris/dynamic contrast it looks like ****!     
Brian.

Backgrounder allows you to put processes in the background (something that a un-jailbroken phone cannot do). Great for keeping your skype on while checking emails etc.    
VOIPover3G to use Skype over your 3G network.   
All these are available on the Cydia store after you jailbreak. They are absolutely necessary imo :P

Not really, the radio connection is a shared resource. If less people are using it, the more bandwidth is available to them, and hence faster speeds. Here's an example of an OVSF tree used for UMTS:       
as you can see, in theory based on Spreading Factors, you can have one guy using the whole bandwidth (SF1), or 16 people taking smaller pieces of it (SF16). The network should automatically scale you to the best connection available.

have you tried       
They indicate that your computer should have come with a DVI adapter.   
That is the best and almost only way to interface your computer with your TV.   
If you have the DVI adapter from when you bought your laptop then you just take the adapter into MediaMart and ask for however much extra length you need.  You can run S-video up to 15 meters with no problem and 20 meters shouldn't be a big issue.  Any more than that starts to cause problems with the video signal.   
If you don't have the adapter you could try Fust at Globus stores, as they carry Apple adapters.  (At least in Lausanne, they do.)   
Good Luck, 
Brian.

I haven't tried popcorn hour, but I've heard it's a great system.   
I have been backing up my collection of DVD's in Ubuntu using a program called K9copy      
I copy them directly as a DVD iso and then play that iso file using an excellent program called VLC,   available for both windows and Ubuntu. One advantage of copying my DVDs this way is I can get rid of all the ads etc at the beginning and make a file where the movie plays immediately. Plus, I can keep extra audio tracks like commentary. Of course, since I am just copying the DVD file, the files are huge.   
For storage I can highly recommend a NAS, the DNS-323. It has a wide support community and works well. You buy the NAS, and the two hard drives it can hold and put it on the network. The nice thing about a NAS is they are like external hard drives but once on your home network, every computer in the house can copy and backup to the NAS. Plus the DNS-323 supports UPnP which means you can use something like popcorn hour to stream programs from the NAS directly to the TV. However, you'd probably have to encode the DVD copy into an avi or something.   
Of course, this is a rather technical solution... but efforts to make easy legal DVD digital backup solutions have been roadblocked (check out this legal effort  , or this link in wikipedia:  )

post:
Hi,   
I wonder how a company is allowed to fleece its customers this way in the so-called developed world. Anyway, I had the same problem with the modem and the fix is the following:   
(a) Does your computer have inbuilt wireless? If so, then forget that USB modem. It is only for older computers with no inbuilt WLAN.    
(b) While setting up the Gigaset, you need to provide information about your service provider. There is usually the choice between "Cablecom" and "Other". You would have logically chosen "Cablecom". Unfortunately, that's the wrong choice if you want to make the modem work. Trust Cablecom to provide such a product.   
Finally, I assume that you made the following connection (wired) while setting things up. Cablecom modem -> Gigaset -> your computer LAN socket.   
Once you have gone through the painful process of configuring your Gigaset, including going to the advanced settings options and turning wireless ON explicitly, you will be able to work with the WLAN. But Siemens products are equally horrible, and so you will need to make a coffee break between every 2 steps of the configuration process.   
And beware! Try not to interrupt the configuration process by going back or closing the browser. If you do that, the wonderful Gigaset configuration will likely never appear again, showing you just a blank screen. I normally turn OFF my WLAN because I use the wired mode in most cases, and since the last time I turned the WLAN ON, it is in ON mode, as I cannot find a way to make the Gigaset configuration appear anymore........   
Vivek

ha ha ha! 
just tuned in to Eurosport 2. Saw 5 mins of the Australia/T&T game. I did not know they were showing the tournament. 
German commentary interspersed with English cricketing terms was really weird.
If you're any good at internet surfing you can download all the latest shows literally 20 mins after they air. Smackdown, RAW, Superstars and all other sorts of wrestlings. PM me for details.

Although I hope you've found a solution to your problem here are my two cents:   
1. Any quad-band (read almost 95% of phones bought in Europe) will work on AT&T or T-Mobile in the US.    
2. Have your iPhone unlocked and use it in the US.     
If your iPhone is not upgraded to the newest firmware which is OS 3.1 and above unlocking your phone will be a piece of cake. PM me and I'll let you in on the details. You don't even have to be a tech junkie to figure it out.    
3. Get a pay monthly account which is NOT a contract.    
Only recently, T-Mobile has started offering service which are prepaid to some extent. As you may already know receiving as well as making calls within the US eats your minutes. If you go with pre pay it will kill your minutes and additional minutes are expensive to come by (I think $0.45 per min). Now depending on how long and how frequently you plan on staying in the US I suggest you sign up for a T-Mobile flex pay account. It will give you a number and all the services of a normal contract while not being one. No Social Security Number needed and you can give any address in the US. You pay in advance for the month of service (yes it is on a month to month cycle) and you will have service for one calender month. If you do not pay for the next month your line will be suspended. A line can be suspended up to 30 days. You can downgrade or upgrade to any plan during any month at no additional fee. For a fee of about $40 you will get around 1000 minutes (for receiving and calling) with unlimited weekends (free domestic calls between Friday 9pm to Monday 6am). Last I checked it was $6.99 for unlimited nights during the weekdays (from 9pm to 6am), 19.99 combined for unlimited data and domestic text messaging (and YES it works with the iPhone although you have to convince T-Mobile you are not using an iPhone - not really a big issue). The best part of course was unlike Europe the data is uncapped so you can make free Skype calls and unlimited browsing over the T-Mobile network without having to worry about overages. Oh and there is a $20 SIM fee if you get pre pay and if you get flex pay they might give it to you for free. I myself have been a T-Mobile customer for 5 years and online research will prove that they are the highest ranked provider for customer satisfaction in the US for cell phone service. For around $82 for the month I had 1000 minutes for nights and weekends and unlimited data and text. You pretty much don't need to pay anything additional. Again if you don't think you'll be spending that many minutes you can opt for a smaller plan. Although be careful if you're going to be in the Manhattan and frequently in the high rise buildings your coverage may be spotty. Anything above the 35th floor is a 50/50. Again this in my opinion is a better option than a pre paid service.    
I hope that helps. If you need any further clarification/help please do let me know.

1) I am not sure any of the Swiss carriers offer a SIM-only plan. Pop into an Orange/Sunrise shop and ask.   
2) I also doubt that the SIM slot in your laptop would necessarily work for this purpose. There is a multitude of tech-standards (GPRS, EDGE, UMTS WCDMA, HSDPA, HSUPA, CDMA2000, EV-DO etc etc) out there, and every operator deploys its own unique mix.   
It MAY be technically possible, but probably not worth the time and effort for the occasional use you are describing.

Most of the swiss providers require a 12 month contract on their plans, but if you go with orange, and bring your own phone, they'll only require a 3 month contract and give you 10 CHF discount on the price.

There is another channel which may interest English speakers, namely the Arte channel. There are both German and French versions of this channel, but only the latter is of interest, as it sometimes shows films in the original language.  
Both channels have two audio tracks, so that one can select either French or German. However the Arte channel from France often puts the original language on the German audio track. As an example of what can be seen, a few days ago there was a film with Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Baccall.    
Here are the tuning details:   
Arte (French):   
Astra (19 deg.), 11566 MHz/s, vertical polarization, 5/6, 22000 KS/s, provider=CANALSATELLITE   
Arte (German):   
Astra (19 deg.), 10743 MHz/s, horizontal polarization, 5/6, 22000 KS/s, provider=ARD   
The EPG on the French Arte channel is poor, showing only the current and the following program, whereas a full EPG is available on the German Arte channel. The two channels show the same program, but the times may differ slightly (French is sometimes 15 minutes earlier than German).

I would assume a strict backup disk is one that is only plugged in and switched on and mounted when you are actually making a backup or retrieveing information from a previous backup. By being kept switched off the rest of the time you are reducing the risk of some incidental virus infection or damage through malfunction. Preferably you are physically keeping the disk in a separate place when not in use which further reduces the risk of it being lost in a fire or stolen etc.   
If for some reason that is not possibly or practicable, you would need a backup disk that conforms to much higher standards.

Deploying a BES server for anything below 500 users and/or below top secret information is pointless. The charges and administration fees are high.    
What you could do is a "hybrid" solution on a budget. I am using Orange's BIS Blackberry service and use a private and a business email on it.    
The private mail is a gmail, nothing much to talk about.   
If you know your business pop3/imap/smtp information, this is a no brainer. If your company however is tough on allowing access from outside through the aforementioned, here is how I went around it.    
My business email is setup to forward copy of each received email to a second gmail. Now, inside gmail you have an option to "send email as" - dig through the settings. Basically, you enter the email that you wish to appear as sender, then gmail generates a confirmation email to this same account. Once you reply to this confirmation, in gmail you will be able to pick from which identity to reply.    
In short, on a single blackberry phone, with BIS you can have up to 10 email accounts set. I use only two - one personal and one business, without need for BES and with the ability to respond as   from the device.    
I hope this info is useful for you - do not hesitate to ask if my tips miss a piece you need.

Well folks... 
I have the dish correctly aligned! There was a local electronics store in my village of Sierentz who sent a guy around with the ladder and sat finder gear - and he took less than a hour (hindered by the few hundred wasps we have this time of year) to correctly align for FreeSat UK channels. 
My mythTV PC now happily records and shows the Free UK channels with no problems, and with much better quality than the digital tiv freeview I had back in the UK (no more signal breakups).   
So - we're all sorted now, chez nous, french tv via adsl2+ and UK (in time for ITV's champions league covereage) TV via sat !    
Anyway - big thanks to all you guys who offered advice etc! 
DANKE! 
Alessandro

NO.   
Designed to work with the SKY Box only.  Uses teh Aerial Coaxial to transmit the IR signal to the SKY box.  The Eye box plugs into the TV inbetween the Coaxial and the SKY box.  This box removed the added voltage necessary for the Magic Eye.  Without this you would fry your TV aerial input (if you enable the Maigc Eye on the SKY box).   
Also the quality is not great, and not sure if this would work with a Swiss TV (encodes the signal for UK TV's) plus probably does not support HD Pictures.

I managed to buy a wifi extender in Hong Kong.  I have never seen one here in Switzerland.     
My Netopia router is on the second floor and barely down to the ground floor.  I installed the extender on the first floor and now have maximum signal throughout four floors of my house.   
It was a little tricky to set up, but now my wifi signal is now extended from the second floor all the way down to my basement where I get a full five bar maximum signal.     
In case you need to extend your wifi as well the name of the device is  "Linksys Wifi G Extender Model WRE54G vers 3.

Teleswiss as above

If you study the market I'd think you'd find the following applies:   
Most TV companies don't want to broadcast DVB-T because the real numbers of actual viewers is soooo small - something like less than 10% of Swiss viewers watch TV over DVB-T   
So most TV companies prefer to use one or more of the 300-ish cable TV operators in this country to reach their market.   
SRG has a federal obligation to provide TV coverage to xx% of Swiss viewers, hence they are on DVB-T. 
They probably would rather not be as cost per viewer is horrendously high.

post:
Phone companies use fully automated systems to log and track and invoice all phone calls.   
There is normally no human involvement at all.   
You can always ask for clariifcation - and they will look into their computer systems and see that the computer logged the call was being made.   
Voice records are normally not kept!   
You best thing to do is go and see the help desk people in person at the nearest service center or help point or whatever they call it. Take the invoice. Tell them what happened. Talk to them in a friendly manner.   
The majority of the time there is a logical reason for what happened, scams are few and far between.

There are many reasons:-   
1: HD is not available in all areas 
2: Double recording 2 channels is not available in all areas 
3: One you have the equipment, no more cost other than a subscription. 
4: Can run up to 8 receivers from one dish. 
5: Multisatellite can give you most of the Bluewin channels. 
6: Choice of receiver - Bluewin is what it is, no deviation 
7: Films in English   
I should add I watch English, French and German TV and have both SKY and Bluewin TV,  from the beginning mainly for French TV, I live in the German region. I can now do more with my satellite equipment that my Bluewin box and I am cancelling my Bluewin subscription.    
On the plus side for Blue Win, it is great for people who want the main English channels and cannot point a dish southwards. I know that you can have a second Blue Win Box, but this is extra cost,  but when the children want to watch a channel and the adults another then it is difficult.

Just out of curiosity, has anyone else noticed that the speech isn't correctly synchronized with the lips on the BBC and ITV channels on Bluwin? I can't work out if it is just an occasional problem or if it is all the time and I notice it only part of the time (at some times it seems worse than at others). I haven't noticed it on the German channels (but I may be focusing too much on the language to notice any other oddities).   
Also, is the screen size format different in CH than in the UK? I can't seem to get the picture to fill the whole screen and I have tried all the options under the bit in the menu where you can choose your screen size. At one point, I got it to work so that I controlled the bluwin TV through my old TV remote control rather than via bluwin and changed the settings on the TV itself (if that makes sense), which made the picture bigger, but still about 5 cm short all round. The picture is slightly smaller when I watch BBC/ITV and slightly larger when I watch the German stations (when it fills the whole screen vertically, but not horizontally). It isn't a big problem, I am just wondering if anyone else had noticed this.    
kfc.   
Have you contacted Bluewin support about this?   
No, I wanted to know first if this was normal. WHen the bluwin TV guy set up my TV, he phoned up about the screen size, but then just left it as it was, so I get the feeling there will be nothing they can do about that. The discussion he had over the phone was in Swiss German, so I didn't understand it, and he had spent 3 hours setting it up, and I was needing to get back to work, so didn't grill him on it at the time.   
Also, I suspect I use my router differently from most people in that I turn it off whenever I am not using it. It is a bit warm to touch and I don't like it being on when I am not in the room. I would probably try keeping it on all the time before phoning bluwin, if I found that my problem with the syncrhonization was unusual. It is possible that after it warms up, the synchronization is OK, since I get too involved in the programme after a while to notice. Just wondered if anyone else had this. Same with the screen size, really, no point in phoning up if it is relatively well-known that screen sizes are different across UK and Switzerland/Germany.   
kfc.   
Synchronisation is perfect for me, also when using the computer. Are you in an area with the latest equipment at the exchange (i.e. can you record 2 shows at the same time?)   
I have a 16:9 screen and 16:9 shows fill it correctly. Programs transmitted in 4:3 are correctly sized i.e. they don't fill the whole screen.   
I have Bluewin. I also noticed the lip-sync but it does disappear sometimes. I also have the little screen with big black spaces but luckily my TV has a screen format button & I push it a couple of times till the picture fits. magic. no problem it works. My TV is a 7 yr old Philips, no HD and not even a flat screen but it works.      I've had a plethora of problems with Bluewin TV and recently switched to Satellite reception (via a Technisat Multytenne, giving me access to all the British FTA channels as well). But I never had sync problems. Did you try to turn off the box and reboot it?  That usually got rid of my choppy picture, choppy sound, no sound, "HD recorder not available", being unable to delete prerecorded programs, deleting corrupted programs, fixing HD-video output issues etc.   
dawiz

Haven't had time yet to do it, though! I have a Lexsor LCD 27" TV in case anyone has a quick tip (not really expecting it, but just thought I would throw it out there).   
kfc.

Yes.... checked it online before ordering... so I did not order.   
I was one of the first to get Bluewin TV (over 2 years ago) despite the fact that my phone line only supported ADSL as VDSL was still in the works (or so they said). Well it's been over 2 years and I'm still waiting for VDSL so I've waited long enough, I'm canceling my Bluewin TV finally. I started with digital TV over my TV cable line (Wasserwerke Zug WWZ) and it blows away anything Bluewin has to offer even if I had VDSL. Best part is that not only can I watch a program while recording another at the same time (which my ADSL line can't support) my digital TV line can record   different channels while I'm viewing a 3rd channel at the same time..!! Lots of HD channels as well..!       Many thanks for your interesting reply vwild!  I must admit my multi-cultural family and I really do enjoy what Bluewin TV offers, so I would be reluctant to change because of the lack of HD - at least for the moment.  I shall just continue to complain to Swisscom! However, I do think Swisscom should be more open to potential Bluewin clients, (a point I have made very clear to them), in informing the latter that the acquisition of Bluewin TV does not automatically give access to HD transmissions!      If you can receive VDSL (and it's easy to find out via the Bluewin Website in English) then the Bluewin TV Plus service can do everything described above (HD channels plus the multiple simultaneous recordings) and for me it gives me more British channels than the local Cablecom can offer at a competitive price.  I installed the system myself and found the English-language instructions spot-on.       
Am I to understand from your post that you are able to receive HD transmissions on your Bluewin TV swiss bill?  Swisscom has told me that my telephone line transmits 12,000 bits? (whatever that may mean!), but 20,000 is needed to receive the HD transmissions. I also opted for the Plus service, and am really happy with Bluewin TV apart from the HD problem.   
Ive had the same problem with HD transmissions, and our phone line transmits at 20,000. I think there is a conflict , when non hd programes transmit. sometimes ours works, sometimes not.  But i find there is virtually no difference between HD and non hd programmes. 
Other than that ive had no problems with Bluewin

Yes, I can confirm that I can receive HD (BBC HD, Swiss HD and possibly ARTE via BTV, but I haven't got round to checking HD channels other than the first two).  I don't know about the number of bits you need, but as far as I remember I checked first on availability by using their website, and entering postal code/ village and that came back with what I could receive at my home.   
I am having problems with my Bluewin TV reception.  The picture "freezes" and blocks, but the sound continues.  This happens on all channels.  Is anyone else experiencing this problem?

Yes, basically if you input a Video and audio signal to the TV, it will work.   
i.e. Via:   
HDMI (Digital Video and Audio) - Best quality 
Component Video + Audio 
SCART (European standard connector, basically a Analogue HDMI) 
S-Video + Audio 
Composite Video + Audio - Worst quality           
European TV's tend to support all SD (Standard Definition) Video formats, including NTSC.   
HD Ready - 720p 
Full HD - 1080p   
702/1080 number of lines. 
P- Progressive scan , updates EVERY line each scan 
I - interlaced, updates every otehr line each scan (i.e. scan 1odd number lines, scan 2 even, scan 3 odd.....)   
Many devices can convert 1080i to 1080p   
HDMI latest standard - 1.3x   
Did I miss something?  Audio formats I guess, but that's another story in itself. Google is your friend

Well there is no such thing as an Astra LNB (that I know of).   
Most LNB's you buy today are: Universal Digital LNB's   
But as mentioned there are specialised one's as well.   
The SKY Oval Dishes need a 'special LNB' where the focal horn is designed for an oval dish.  SO the LNB from a SKY oval dish will not work so well on a normal round dish.

post: If you have phone wiring in house then you can connect one wire from modem to one of your normal phone sockets (use a splitter if you need phone near modem), and then connect phones anywhere in house to regular phone sockets. It works for me. I have phone wiring over three floors and one socket is connected to modem (socket will have bigger swiss connector and modem will have rj11 plug, the phone wire that comes with modem will do the job).

Plugged it in (it does English no probs), let it do it's thing and I now have all BBC broadcastings (including CBeebies, Wooh!!) and "Five".

In fact, it has a double bonus for me, our original t.v remote control went to t.v remote control heaven some time ago and the (cheapo) universal remote control I got, works, as such, but all the fine tuning options were lost.    
Now after getting this little dandy all set up, I have a new remote control that syncs with the universal remote I have and has somehow, automatically adjusted the picture quality and format (very much improved!) on our t.v.

post:
My understanding of this was a little different. BBC were all paying Sky to be on their satellite  bandwidth and program guide. As part of this agreement their channels were encrypted and you needed a sky viewing card to decrypt them. But at time went on, the BBC didn't see the value in paying sky for this service, so switched to another satellite in the Astra cluster. Sky realised they still needed the BBC, as they produce the majority of the UKs high quality television, so didn't remove them from the EPG. But as the signals was no longer encrypted there was no way to ensure that only the license payers in the UK got the BBC. Sky can broadcast over a large area with strong signals as they "know" all their views are in the UK. Sky installed the box, it's plugged into a UK phone line you have a valid viewing card registered at/send to a UK address. With their open signals the BBC can't ensure this, so have tried to focus the signal purely on the UK which is why you have a weaker signal for the free to air (FTA) channels as opposed to the others, including the free to view (FTV), which can be watched without subscription, but require a viewing card.    
Or at least that is what I think happened...

In my post of April 05 I assumed that the Swisscom max 8.07 Rp would be on top of what the provider charges. It seems that the total maximum charge on 0840 numbers is 8.07 Rp. Having used Tieftarife for a while and checking my online Swisscom bills I see that when Tieftarife charges 1 Rp a call indeed costs around that. "Around" because the billing seems to be in 10 Rp bits, so it's never precise. 
However with UK at 2 Rp and USA at 1 Rp they are much cheaper than 10787 and also easier to use as you just pay through your Swisscom bill. 
Quality of the line has been excellent each time so far.

Repeaters simply amplify the received signal and retransmit it. Any capacity involved is from the donor base station where the repeater is getting the signal from. If anything, repeaters actually help improve capacity in UMTS networks by reducing interference.   
The problem with trains is the speed they move at make handovers between cells a problem. Plus the increased fading margins that also come at high speeds.

post:
Clever!   
But what the video doesn't say is that you need to rotate the can/phone until the open (front of phone) is pointing at the nearest cellphone base station. If you don't know where that is, try rotating SLOWLY whilst watching the signal level icon on the phone. Make sure as few objects, (metal, walls, people) are in the line of the phone to that distant cellphone base station as these soak up the signal.   
SMS's will often get through when signal levels are much too low for a conversation.   
You can attach a headset once you've got the orientation right. If your headset has a call answer button you won't need to pick it up. Better still if it has voice-activated dialling.   
But a proper directional external antenna will give even better results.   
RS

NHL in Europe is streamed LIVE (and archived for later viewing) through ESPN America (ESPN 360 in Europe).       
The fees:    
NHL Playoff pass - 54 CHF (this includes rest of season, ALL playoff games, and the cup final).   
NHL Early bird pass - 144 CHF (INCLUDES the playoffs, needs to be purchased before season starts).    
NHL Monthly Recurring pass - 24 CHF   
NHL Day pass - 14 CHF   
They have low quality streams and high quality streams you can choose (depending on your connection). All games are EST.    
Works on MAC and PC. Games are FULLSCREEN. Quality is great.
You are luckier than some to have a choice of either DSL or Cablecom for Internet without incurring extra charges !

post:
Data compression is a good thing but it really only works for e-mail. Web-Browsing will still eat up your included volume very quickly and roaming will be very expensive. The 3mb that's included in the roaming option is enough for about 1500 e-mails (without attachments - which aren't automatically downloaded with the blackberry service) according to Swisscom.   
They have the "Euro passport" option that can be added (for free) to all subscriptions. That lowers the tariffs for calls within most European countries to 1.10 CHF for the first minute and 60 Rp for all subsequent minutes. Incoming calls are 40 Rp per minute.  
That's still insanely expensive but it's about the same as with any other European carrier.       
If you plan on calling European or US landlines from your mobile (from within Switzerland) a lot, Orange will be cheaper for you - they charge calls to EU countries as domestic calls. You can even use up your included minutes for calls to these countries.    
Anyway, despite these options voice and data abroad is still so expensive that I hardly ever use my phone when I'm outside of Switzerland.   
Peter

Well I found (typically daft) workaround to get the HTC HD to play live streaming BBC World Service radio.   
This workaround uses the Windows Internet Explorer(IE) + Media Player rather than Opera + Streaming Player combo I was expecting.    
Oh well here goes....   
Bookmark :     
In Windows Internet Explorer (or Opera) click on the GotRadio link and this will open up a stream of American RnB / droning teen rock BUT it does work and open up a functioning 'live' stream In Windows Media Player. 
This takes about 30 seconds to get audio.   
Next open up your bookmarked link to BBC World Service in IE :       
this will show an error page saying you don't have the correct plug ins. So click on the Launch in Stand Alone Player and it will launch in Windows Media Player.   
Make sure you connect using WIFI or you'll get a massive data bill. Also when you play without earphones the speaker is on the back of the unit so place the phone face down for extra volume.   
If you have problems with the BBC site you may need to go to the BBC site go to preferences and make Desktop Connection and Windows Media Player as your IE browser's default settings.   
I'm sure there's an easier method (go and replace your HTC phone with a Nokia that does radio streaming of BBC radio effortlessly) but I just figured this out and thought I'd pass it on.

Yes but:   I've just looked up the prices for iWork and iLife in the UK (£69 for the single user version, £85 for the Family License Pack vs CHF 109/139 here). At the current mid-rate of 1 GBP = 1.69287 CHF (from  ) it is cheaper to buy here at the moment (69.00 GBP = 116.808 CHF).   
Those are VAT inclusive prices of course, and the UK VAT element for the £69 single user version comes to £9.00 (versus Swiss VAT of CHF 7.70 on the price of CHF 109 here). If you are going to claim UK VAT back and then pay the Swiss VAT here, it's cheaper to buy in the UK.   
It doesn't make much difference at this price level, but if you are thinking about buying the high end products and are planning a visit to another country anyway, there are potential savings to be made.

I recorded it and finally watched this excellent film based on a true story.   
However it was totally ruined for me by two really stupid 'continuity' problems. As the real patient went to Zurich in January, the film story line showed the family going out to Zurich then too, soon after Christmas. But what did they find here? Switzerland in mid-summer! Trees with leaves and despite the family wearing thick coats the background public could clearly be seen in shirt sleeves through the taxi window.   
And that taxi. How come they had the same taxi to and from the airport and every time they took a trip?    
I have actually written in the past to the BBC about their series 'Casualty' when inside the hospital they had Christmas decorations up, but outside it was summer and a new doctor drove to work through leafy streets in a convertible with the roof down. I asked what was the point of taking such pride in getting the medical aspects correct, if they made such fundamental bloomers. 'A Short Trip to Switzerland' suffered the same indignity...
How about 1 of these Selfsats? Are they an good for Sky?

It would presumably have been simple if they could only send out the right modem with the right username/password.    
I had a total of 3 modems sent out to me. Every time I tried to hook it up, it wouldn't work. I called support and they say for each time "sorry, we've sent you the wrong modem and the username/password won't work with it. Can you please send that modem back to us?"    
Apparently, whoever took my details had entered in some wrong bit of info. However, they could seem to correct it as each time I call, the wrong info remained even after the previous call where they assured me the details had been corrected and they would then be able to send me a modem that works.    
Well, after the third time, I got sick of it and went to Swisscom. Hooked up with in a couple days and their tech support were superb and spoke excellent English to boot.    
Later, I got a bill from Cablecom charging me for mailing the modem which never worked. I paid it because I just couldn't bear to deal with Cablecom anymore.    
The long and short is the Cablecom may seem cheap but you pay for it when it comes to customer care and technical support.

Thank you all for the suggestions, highly appreciated !   
Shall go surf whist eating the wife's pringles (they taste sooooo much better) I knew watching Blue Peter and those bad boys at Magpie would pay dividends one day .....30 years later but hey !! and it only dawn on me last year that a Navatooby Trove was secret 'never to be told' ??   
For the more observant of Basel residents I can be spotted opposite the Kaserne tram shivering on the balcony whilst I get a better signal.

post:
Hi All,   
I just picked up my new Touch HD a few weeks ago, and I have to say it's the best phone I've ever had, by far (my previous two phones were an HTC TyTN II and a Samsung Blackjack, so I'm used to WM).  I acknowledge the frustration that the original poster has, but I think a lot of the negatives are a result of the reviewer moving to a new OS, and admittedly, WM6 is not the greatest mobile OS.  That being said, I think HTC has done a great job with this phone;s interface.  And on this beautiful (and HUGE!) screen, it looks fantastic.  I've played around with a few friends' iPhones, and I find that my Touch HD is just a better phone (and is much more flexible).  Here's what the HD (or most WM phones) can do that the iPhone can't:   
1. Multitask (you can run several programs at the same time) - iPhone is a single task OS, I Believe 
2. Add additional storage (the phone ships with an 8G microSD card, which you can upgrade to 32GB 
3. Turn by Turn navigation (I have TomTom installed, and it works really really well 
4. Removable battery (great if you are a heavy user and like to carry around a spare battery) 
5. FM Radio tuner built in   
And in terms of hardware specs, the Touch HD is better in just about every department (higher resolution screen, bigger screen, better camera, etc)   
Also, regarding some of the original complaints, there is a great site that has all sorts of software (including entirely custom ROM's) for the Touch HD:       
I installed one of the custom ROMs that lets me play youtube videos within my Opera Browser.   
Just wanted to chime in, as I felt the original review was extremely negative (and as someone else pointed out, this phone has mostly rave reviews from the tech press).   
Oh, btw... I bought my phone from Expansys.uk (shipped by Expansys.ch) for about 700CHF, unlocked.  Expensive, I know, but much better than the 800+ CHF I see on Digitec, and other sites.   
Cheers, 
Tony

post:
Source:          
===By Jeremy Kirk, IDG News Service=== 
  December 04, 2008     
     Researchers at BitDefender have discovered a new type of malicious software that collects passwords for banking sites but targets only Firefox users.   
The malware uses JavaScript to identify more than 100 financial and money transfer Web sites, including   along with two dozen or so  . When it recognizes a Web site, it will collect logins and passwords, forwarding that information to a server in Russia.   
Firefox has been continually gaining market share against main competitor Internet Explorer since its debut four years ago, which may be one reason why malware authors are looking for new avenues to infect computers, Canja said.   
Users could be infected with the Trojan either from a drive-by download, which can infect a PC by exploiting a vulnerability in a browser, or by being duped into downloading it, Canja said.   
When it runs on a PC, it registers itself in Firefox's system files as "Greasemonkey," a well-known collection of scripts that add extra functionality to Web pages rendered by Firefox.   
BitDefender has updated its products to detect it, and other vendors will likely follow suit quickly, Canja said. Users could avoid it by only downloading signed, verified software, but that's a measure that restricts the usability of a PC, he said.   
The malware is not present in Mozilla's repository of add-ons, Canja said. Mozilla had taken steps to ensure that its official site hosting add-ons -- also called extensions -- are free from malware.   
In May, Mozilla acknowledged that the Vietnamese language pack for  
Firefox contained a bit of unwanted code. Although widely reported as a virus, the language actually contained a line of HTML code that would cause users to view unwanted advertisements.   
Mozilla now scans new add-ons for malware. However, those scans will only detect known threats, and there was no signature in the security software Mozilla was using at the time that could detect the code.   
Mozilla said the code probably ended up in the language pack after the PC of its developer became infected. More than 16,000 people downloaded the language pack, but only about 1,000 people regularly use it.   
After the incident, Mozilla said it would scan add-ons in its repository when antivirus signatures were updated.

post: I'll have to check this tonight, when I am at home.  But just so I know I am checking the right place where should that information be.  (as I said previously I am a bit computer oblivous)

I'm often accused of being cynical and unkind to the locals. This is, of course, incorrect. I am very cynical and extremely unkind to the locals (I have my reasons).   
Having said that I must praise Cablecom for my recent encounter.    
I started to have problems with my internet and telephone connection. The sound quality on the telephone calls was getting worse and the intenet connection seemed to be lacking bandwidth.   
I filled in the on-line questionnaire (in English) on Wednesday morning. I got a telephone call in the afternoon and arranged a visit for this morning. When the guy didn't show at the right time I thought I was going to be in for some standard Swiss service. Five minutes later however I got an apologetic phone call telling me he was running twenty minutes late.   
Sure enough, he showed up twenty minutes later. He then proceeded to fiddle around in the way that telephone engineers do for around twenty minutes. He replaced a couple of small pieces and hey-presto I now have much better reception and my bandwidth is, dare I say, impressive once more.   
So, thank you Cablecom. I know you take a lot of flack sometimes but I, for one, have never had any problems with your service.

Thanks man.   
Keep it real.

Not sure what you mean.   
If this is a Monoblock set at 6.2 degrees (for 13.0 & 19.2) and you now use this this for Astra 2 (28.x) then the second LNB will be 6.2 +/- 28.x (depending which is aimed at 28.x).   
I assume this monoblock just has a single output?  If yes, this will contain a switch to allow a box to select LNB 1 or 2.  This means the decoder needs to be setup to do this via DiSeQ codes.   
If there is more than one output, often Input 1 has to be active (receive power) to drive the switch and second LNB.   
NOt sure if this answers your Q.   
If you are getting Some Astra 2 channels but not BBC, ITV etc.. you eitehr need to fine tune the dish or have a bigger setup as these channels are on a more focussed footprint which we are on the edge of.   
See previous posting with footprints of Astra 2D

post: For the benefit of anyone else with this issue:  I called Swisscom and they told me their normal contracts are for a year but they can "make an exception" for a 6-month contract.  So supposedly the line will be connected when I arrive and it's only for 6 months.

For those interested in receiving British FTA programs:  Lyngsat pushed a new channel list to their Lyngbox sat receiver last night - now ITV HD is included.    
The Lyngbox also comes with full listings for most (if not all) British FTA channels. The available channels can be found here:    
The receiver can even be programmed directly over the internet.    
I wouldn't recommend the box to anyone using German Pay TV (Premiere) yet - there are lots of bugs in connection with the Alphacrypt and Diablo CAMs. But it's an alternative for those who were contemplating the purchase of a Freesat rec in the UK. 
All in all, it's somewhat buggy - but most bugs are only annoying to pay tv subscribers (e.g. it only tapes one audio channel at the moment - automatic audio channel selection doesn't work on Premiere - but it works on Swiss TV, for example) etc.    
I bought one for the EPG / tv listings but I'm torn whether I should keep it or not - I'm a Premiere subscriber and the issues are very annoying to me.   
peter

Does your fixed line modem have a router built in? If so, buy a seperate WLAN router (like gregv suggested) and just plug it to a spare ethernet port. "Wireless G" (802.11g) standard wifi routers/access points are really cheap now because the N version (802.11n) has a pre-release out now and offers data rates up to 270Mbps, I got an 802.11g AP and USB dongle for 40CHF at Steg ( )   
Almost all 802.11g AP's are backwards compatible with 802.11b so you can use it with your internal wifi card also.
Cablecom sends you a post-paid sticker with their address on it, and if your modem is very old they might not be interested in getting it back. You'll have to contact them to be sure.

Connection possibilities, ordered from best to worst quality, all available on the Mediabox SCART connector:   
1. YUV ( YPbPr )  video (component).    
2. S-VHS video.   
3. Composite PAL video   
Whichever you use depends on what the beamer has available as inputs.   
Google tells me the Mitsubishi HD1000 has the following:     Connection Panel: One HDMI port, one 15-pin VGA port, one set of YPbPr component inputs, one s-video input, one composite video input, one 12V trigger, one serial port, and one USB port.    
You want to u se the  YPbPr component inputs.   Just purchase the appropriate SCART to  YPbPr component  cable to connect the two. 
As a beamer is normally used to generate  a physically large picture, I strongly recommend you go for the component solution for the sharpest picture.

Hi all,   
I recently tried to set up my old pc (runing windows XP) with my CableCom modem. The pc wouldn't recognise the modem, even though I was using it with a laptop at the same time via USB, so there was no issue with the modem.   
Anyway, someone from CC technical, came back with this fix and it worked: Restart the pc and turn off any firewall, turn off cc modem for 20 secs, connect the ethernet cable to the pc, then reboot the modem.    
My pc connected straight away, just like the laptops had, no need for any of the software supplied by CC nothing, so just thought I'd share it on here if someone else has a problem.

Yes, if you connect the cablecom digital TV tuner (settop box) to your display's AV-IN using standard AV cables.   
The AV still contains PAL 625-line 50Hz video, so your TV will need to be able to accept 625-line 50Hz PAL signals on the AV-IN   
Your NTSC/ATSC/QAM tuner is worthless here as there is no NTSC or ATSC transmission in Europe. ie: nothing for the tuner to receive.   
Also, unless the TV is multi-voltage, you'll need a transformer to convert Euro 230V to US 110V.

post:
You have an earth-leakage safety detector (RCD) tripping.   
One of your devices has too much earth current, ie: is technically unsafe   
One house has a safety-detecting breaker (called an RCD or residual current device, designed to protect you from electric shocks). This is doing its job, and switching off the power when it detects the fault.   
The other house will have no RCD and so will have no ability to trip.   
You should get all the devices which were connected to the TV checked: the DVD player, satellite receiver, video recorder, and TV.   
Or connect them one by one, until you find the one that trips the breaker.   
A friend with a multimeter and electrical knowledge could determine this for you very quickly.   
Otherwise, ring your local electrical supply authority - they may well offer free safety testing in their offices / showrooms etc. Ask them.

We've been using Unlimited World subscription and have been very happy about it ( ). 
It's around $20 for three months (with the current promotion) and gives you three phone numbers within the zone of the "unlimited world." One can pay in yearly installments as well.   
For those who still have ties to the US, this is very convenient: you can wait on hold for a bank or a credit card company representative for quite some time and then it will take them hours to verify your identity   For us, it's also useful to have a US phone number, for various reasons. Cell phones in US and Canada (+ a few other countries) are included in the subscription.   
Skype is working even with a not-so-great WiFi connection that we currently have. Also, with this subscription, you can call the landlines in the countries that are not part of the "unlimited world." Calling a Moscow landline is, for instance, $0.024 per minute.

post: Someone is selling a x series in Basel with a 3yr warranty

Ok guys,   
I have spoken to my lawyer and the mietverband and its perfectly legal in Switzerland to have a satellite dish as long as its on your balcony and not attached to it. If it says it in your contract that you cant have one dont worry this only applies to Swissys who have already got access to their local channels, as a foreigner you have the informationsrecht to get access to your home tv. My verwaltung also confirmed to me today that the clause is worthless in my contract.   
I am getting my lawyer to write a letter to my verwaltung telling them to stop bothering me about it and I will distribute copies of this to my wonderful backward swiss neighbours letterboxes.    
At last there is an advantage to being foreign here    
This is the final answer for anyone wondering about sat dishes for confirmation they should ring the miterverband who will tell them the exact same thing.

Winterthur is served by Cablecom. You can check the availability of all services on the  , but generally, every location in the city of Winterthur with an existing cable connection should be well served.   
1. Yes, if your TV is a multi-standard TV. Check the user manual, the TV standard used in Switzerland is PAL B/G. The UK uses PAL-I. 
If your TV is PAL-I only, then you can only connect via AV or SCART. You cannot use the analogue tuner. If the TV is PAL-I only, and more than 2 years old, consider selling it in the UK.   
2) As you wish. There are a couple of analogue cable TV English speaking channels, but there are 11 English speaking channels on digital cable TV (DVB-C). Digital free over-the-air (DVB-T) is restricted to just 4 x Swiss channels, plus anything you may be lucky enough to get from Austria and Germany, depending on your location. There is no more analogue over-the-air TV. 
However digital cable TV is encrypted and you must use a Cablecom digital settop box, so there is no point buying a TV with builtin DVB-C digital TV tuner.   
3) Depends what you want to receive. For satellite: shop around. For cable TV: you can only use the Cablecom settop box.   
4) All info is here:   
You get BBC Prime. BBC 1, BBC 2, BBC World, ITV 1, ITV 2, CNN, CNBC, Al Jazeera, Film4, and Fashion TV as native English channels, all included in the basic digital TV offering. 
Plus many programs and movies are shown in multi-language, with English being the most common 2nd language. So I watch Greys Anatomy on SF2 in English.   
5) If your digital radio is DAB, then yes. The Swiss use the same DAB standard. Should work.     
There is a small fee of 6 CHF per month to rent the cablecom digital TV receiver. No recorder function. Full details  . 
If you want the digital receiver with built in recorder (what I have) the price is 10 CHF per month (on top of the satdnard apartment connection fee, which is normally included in the rent), but the first 3 months are half price (or first 6 months if you buy another Cablecom product)   
If you will own your own house/apartment, then you part the standard service fee of around 20 CHF per month (pays for the analogue TV and radio), plus any additional services like digital TV receiver etc.   
Cablecom also do very good internet deals, their internet speeds are fantastic - I get 15Mbps - and the pries are very reasonable.

oh nooo!  ...

The box is the receiver.   
In the old analogue TV days, the receiver was integrated with the screen. 
In the new digital world, the receiver is often separate from the screen   
So for every screen you have, you need a receiver.   
Your receiver choices are: 
Analogue, built in 
DVB-C, built in, non-cablecom 
DVB-C. separate, cablecom 
DVB-S, built-in 
DVB-S, separate 
DVB-T. built-in 
DVB-T, separate 
BluwinTV, separate   
The general rule today is to select the screen of your choice carefully, and then select the appropriate receiver for what you want to receive   
The reason is that you expect the screen to have a life-span of around 10 years, but the receiver will most likely change within 3 to 5 years.   
A separate receiver and separate screen gives you flexibility have multiple screens connected to one receiver, or have multiple receivers and multiple screens, all either operating independently, or interconnected   
The old analogue days of one choice only are almost fully behind us :-)

If you have just one line with one provider it probably won't offer a huge advantage to you TBH.   
If you have multiple lines you can use lowest cost routing (rules which route the call through the cheapest provider), you can also route incoming calls to the correct handset.   
E.g. In addition to our Gigaset IP phones our Nokia phones have a built in SIP client, and automatically join the wifi network when at home. It would be nice if all incoming calls on our Paris number rang the missus phone and all incoming calls on our London number ring mine. All outgoing calls would use Voipstunt unless they were to a mobile phone in which case they could take a different provider.   
In short you gain total control of your telephony.

Note that the owner of the building is responsible for all of the in-building cabling, as it physically belongs to him.   
To change the current socket from one room to another is not always easy or possible.   
I managed to do it once where, luckily, I had a socket on both sides of a wall. So all I needed was a screwdriver.   
But sometimes it is much harder than that. 
Wireless solutions vary depending on what you want to do.   
For internet, a WiFi router can be plugged into the existing Cablecom socket and then you can enjoy internet all over the house. Typical routers cost between 50 and 100 sFr.   
For telephone, again you can connect a cordless phone to the Cablecom modem and enjoy wireless telephone throughout the house. costs for a cordless phone are well under sFr 100   
For television, you can use a Cablecom digital TV receiver on the existing socket, and then connected to a wireless video sender, which has a two-way connection for the remote control. Then you can have the TV anywhere in the house.  Not sure of the price of such wireless video senders but they can be found in various shops like InterDiscount. 
If you want just the stone age analogue TV, then it will be much harder. You may have no solution other than extending the cable.   
Depending on the construction of your apartment, such wireless solutions may be the easiest and cheapest way to 'shift' the current cable TV socket from one room to another.

post:
Finally done it!!!!!!!!!!   
It works - as a DVD player and a recorder.   
Step 1. Connect main TV aerial into set-top-box 
Step 2. Connect an aerial lead from set-top-box to DVD 
Step 3. Connect an aerial lead from the set-top-box to TV   
Step 4. Connect set-top-box to TV (AV1) with a SCART 
Step 4. Connect DVD to TV (AV2) with a SCART   
Connections finished!   
The link which I found most useful:-    
However on my TV you have to retune a channel on the TV, so that that channel "sees" the Video signal, and in the setup of the TV, you have to tell it to scan AV2 in my case as a MONITOR.   
Also tell DVD to rescan all channels.   
I now can play DVD and record from the TV channels, I still cannot record from the new channels provided by the set-top-box.

post: From my experience in the UK, the one sure fire way to deal with that is to swear at them. hi salsa lover,   
sounds like you are convincing yourself to go the plasma route.    
im sure that you will be happy with whatever you choose. you do tend to get what you pay for in this field, and also, these TV´s are getting better and better at what they do so it pays to buy the latest. of course, there is also a fine balance to be struck between screen size and cost.   
When your budget is not so big, but you need a big screen, probably plasma is for you.    
When you can afford a bit more, or dont mind having a smaller screen, then check out lcds.   
If you see a good deal on a model you like, then note down the model number and google the model number followed by the word "review"... then you can get some ideas about what people think of it.    
I personally prefer to go with LCD, i find the picture sharper and more pleasing than plasma. It is true that lcd is becoming more and more popular while plasma is declining. One big reason for this is that smaller screen lcds tend to have higher resolutions than plasma, 32 inches being the most popular lcd size (although now 40 inches is slowly becoming the standard), while it IS true that plasma is more likely to suffer burn in than LCD.... I have seen plenty of examples of this with my own eyes so i dont need to read any big research report.    
Also, dont forget to check out some internet retailers... I can recommend   who do keen prices on both lcd and plasma. They are located in Zug and have a showroom there, so you can normally go over and have a look for yourself.    
If you are quite quality conscious about the picture, then just spend a bit more than you normally would. chf 500 more today might mean that you are much happier with the image for several years.

I can't tell you about cost because we've not received a bill yet, despite having the service for about 2 months.  It seems to be a reliable, reasonable product, certainly as good, if not better than what I had in the US (unbundled broadband, cable and landline). Not sure if that says much.    
When we checked prices,  it did appear that quickline was the best deal  - we call a lot to the US. The telephone service is fine - good and clear, no weird echo on the cordless when we're talking to a moblie or to a phone in the US. We have digital TV, but we're borrowing a tiny TV and we just have basic channels. The selection of channels is ok, I guess. I don't watch a lot of TV.  The internet is reliable. There are three internet options - we're on the lowest speed, and it's been up all the time and  certainly no worse than the cable modem i had in the US. When I  connect to the system that I'm working on in the US via VPN, I find it sluggish - considerably more sluggish than when I lived 3 miles away from the system.  We're thinking of upgrading once I start to work more regularly.    
I'm in Bern, btw - Belp, actually. Hope that's somewhat helpful.    
e.

Hi,   
I had a similar experience when I first moved into our apartment where they accepted my order online, and then unbeknownst to me they canceled it. I called customer service and managed to get through to a human - I understand and speak reasonable French, so it is a help to get through the menus. I was lucky enough to get an English speaking agent the first time, and they explained to me that although the connection was there the owner of the building had not signed the contract so the street connection had not been made.    
I then explained to the person on the other end, that I was currently receiving analog Cable television so therefore the connection was up and running, and they insisted that it was impossible.    
Bottom line was that they had to place a new order for me. The good news is that I never got billed for the first one. Bad news is they cancelled my second order, which I did not get billed for either, for the same reason.    
I called again and asked for an English speaking agent, and if one was not available at the time, but they were really good about calling me back.   
When I got the callback I placed a new order, and the agent made some special entry on the record, and as they say third time is a charm, I finally got my Highspeed Internet and Telephone service.    
Overall the experience was not good, but the agents were always very helpful.   
Hope you get it sorted. 
Jose

However, I only expect to be in this apartment for 3 months (although I'll be in Zurich for longer), which seems to rule out any of the ADSL or cable offerings that all seem to have a 12-month contract.   
So I was looking around for wireless broadband options. So far, I've only found Swisscom NATEL (hideously expensive for daily/permanent use) and Sunrise "T@KE-AWAY", which seems reasonable but also has a 12-month minimum contract. I can live with that, but when I do move in a few months I'd prefer to get cable or ADSL than be stuck on a wireless contract.   
So the question that I'm coming to is: are there any other wireless broadband providers worth considering, or is there any way to get a broadband for a shorter time period?   
I noticed that both Swisscom and Sunrise are HSPDA networks; in Sydney there were other network technologies being marketed as iBurst and Unwired, is there anything similar here that I've missed?   
Thanks for any advice, 
Andrew

As someone who used to dabble in VRML on Silicon Graphics hardware when I should have been building molecular models, I thought I'd have a look at Second Life. I am not interested in the social aspect of SL.   
So I tried it for a few hours late last year. I found it slow and jerky. Cumbersome inyerface [sic], worse even than Google Earth. A CPU hog. Their servers are slow.   
You get to customise a 3D model of your own avatar. You can fly, run, walk, teleport. There is chat and also voice chat (I haven't tried voice chat).   
There seems to be a potentially powerful system for constructing objects and animations and so on. But, like most 3D editors, it's not easy to use.  And again, there is the annoying lag. There is some sort of scripting language for assigning behaviours to the things you build but I haven't tried to use it.   
You can use real money to buy SL currency and buy and sell and make things in the SL world.   
Your post prompted me to try again. I installed a mandatory update and reconnected. This time, slightly less jittery, but still a cumbersome interface. Better response might be due to my 10MBit connection though.
Gee, thanks guys

Wikipedia is your friend!       
"Regional division"   
The Nintendo DS is   in the sense that any console will run a Nintendo DS game purchased anywhere in the world; it is the same system everywhere. However, the Chinese version games can only be played on the Chinese iQue DS, whose larger firmware chip contains the required   glyph images. Nintendo DS of other regions cannot play the Chinese games, while iQue DS can play games of other regions. Also, as with Game Boy games, some games that require both players to have a Nintendo DS Game Card for multiplayer play will not work together if the games are from different regions (e.g. a Japanese Nintendo DS game may not work with a North American Nintendo DS game, though some titles, such as  , are mutually compatible). With the addition of the  , certain games can be played over the Internet with users of a different region game.   
So the answer is yes.

post:
I can confirm that although the Bluewin-supplied ADSL and VDSL routers have WiFi, you can't stream TV over this as the available bandwidth is just not high enough (whatever the over-inflated claims are!) You HAVE to connect the router and the Bluewin IPTV box with a conventional Ethernet cable.   
One trick used by the Bluewin installers is to move the incoming telephone cable to a point behind the TV. This cable is just a thin copper pair and is easier to hide than an Ethernet cable. Sometimes a (now defunct) TV antenna cable duct and socket can be used to reroute this cable.   
Once the router is thus connected with the phone line behind the TV, one can then use a very short patch cable to connect the IPTV box. PC connections to the router can then be made wirelessly, as the limited speed of WiFi is not usually an issue when browsing/emailing.   
The only remaining issue is telephones. I simply hooked a Siemens Gigaset Dect cordless base to the incoming phone line - problem solved.   
HOWEVER - if you can't use the solution outlined above, Swisscom are actively testing (6/07) an alternative that involves using a very thin plastic optical fibre (just 1.5mm dia) as an Ethernet extension. This is also a Siemens Gigaset product, which rejoices in the (English on the box) product name "Gigaset Optical LAN Adapter Duo". The product consists of a cardboard box that contains two identical small white boxes with indicator LEDs. Each box has an Ethernet and a fibre socket, and needs volts from a small wall transformer. No configuration at all is required - it's quite literally "plug and play". So the connections are: Router Ethernet socket via Ethernet patch cable to white box, to fibre (30m suppplied - user can shorten), to 2nd white box, to 2nd Ethernet patch cable and finally to the IPTV box. The 2 short patch cables, 30m fibre, fibre cutter, wall transformers and English/French/German instructions are all in that single box.   
I don't know where this can be purchased as the one I have I'm testing is here in my office/lab, but Siemens Gigaset stuff is freely available in CH. I also don't (yet) know if Swisscom will sell or provide this as part of the Bluewin TV install service.   
Note that this Gigaset product allows you to extend ANY standard Ethernet up to 30m using a very thin fibre, so it's uses are not limited to IPTV. I imagine it could be pretty useful to renters who need to easily extend a true 100Mbits/s Ethernet invisibly around an apartment and can't/don't want to use much slower WiFi. It also doesn't care at all about Mac/PC/Linux issues! For the tecchies, it's IEEE 802.3u.   
Richard S

Hi.   
All DSL over a phone line at the moment is done through Swisscom - up until very recently they legally owned the so called "last mile".  The upshot is, if you get a connection using a phone line  from anyone, you will have to pay Swisscom for the line - 25.25 I believe for analog.  To have DSL from swisscom will cost you more of course.  If you opt for DSL from say sunrise, you will then pay for that on a separate bill (but still the 25.25 from Swisscom).  There is ongoing legal challenges to this crazy situation.  Hopefully the situation will be completely different by the end of next year and the consumer will benefit from real competition  .   
If you go for a cable option, e.g. Cablecom, then you pay only them and will have 1 x bill.   
In all cases, be careful what you choose.  I would not recommend a pay as you go type deal, these almost invariably work out more expensive for the consumer than an unlimited usage deal.

Hi LOB and everyone.  I have found a solution.  It is a kludge but it works.   
If I want to tape something onto my DVD recorder and I will not be there, I put in 2 programs for the time.  The first one I enter in the planner for recording must be the program I want the tv to switch to.  The second can be anything.    When you have 2 programs recording at the same time, and the tv is on a different channel, it will switch the tv to the program you first entered.  (not the first one in the list)   
I then just delete it from the skyplus box after.  This allows the tv to change when I am not in the room.     
It records to the dvd-r, so I do not have to copy it later.   
LOB - thanks for the hard disk forum input.  I read it, and found a company in zurich which has a large hard disk for the sky plus box for 100chf plus shipping.     
kind regards

thread: i am enable to go to internet

post:
Both POTS (analog) and ISDN (digital) lines are available in Switzerland. The analog option is cheaper and more common.   
If your phone is powered from the line, it should work. If it is has a locally powered base station (DECT) or answering function then you will have a problem with the 230v power.   
That being said my advice would be, don't bother bring such small things. Have a garage sale sell them off and buy some new ones here, because you will at the very minimum need to buy new cables or converters from RJ-11 to the local connector (TT) here.

  To the OP: Putting a dish on a balcony, assuming it faces the right way, is surprisingly easy.  Just get a vertical mounting pole and screw/drill it into a paving slab.  Then run the leads under your balcony door using a short, flat cable specially designed for the job.  No changes to your doors or building required, which should keep the owners of the building happy.

Hello Aline,   
Be very carefull with what you read on Cablecom website....  what you have seen  only means that you might have * the possibility * to get hispeed. The site only says that you can have, not if it is installed or not. There used to be a small disclaimer about it.    
In case you are the misfortunate first customer of the building to request it, you might have to face a 12 week delay before they sort out things with the landlord (contracts have to be signed, etc), and install the amplifier. I can tell you that it took them 9 weeks to have the whole thing done.    
In despair, i ended up to go for Swisscom. It took them less than 24h to have the phone connected and 5 working days for the ADSL, including the new modem.   
If you call cablecom, the most likelly thing is that they answer that a technician will have to check. Then start counting. I would recommend that you contact the landlord to double check if hispeed is indeed available. Also try to get the name of previous owner of the flat. It would make your life much easier.   
In any case, good luck with both move and internet conexion.

Sorry about the repetition - comes from replying to multiple threads then getting interrupted by a phone call from the gerance or next hotel I have to book into etc. and forgetting what I just posted about.  I'm sure you remember the chaos of setting up that you'll have had to go through before and all the things you need to learn to do at once, especially with an apartment!      
I think I WILL phone cablecom closer to the time I move in, but regardless of the language or country, I've found it always helps to know something beforehand, as it's in any company's best interests to keep you believing they are the best/only etc option.  And whilst in Switzerland I have had some frosty receptions when I professed to not know the proper system when talking to various agencies - even when using my fair understanding of French!  That's something that's surprised me here - often there is sympathy for language issues, but not so much if you don't know the processes.     
Thanks to all for the responses to my queries so far - I've learned a lot.  I've been passing what I learn on to the seeming flood of new postdocs arriving in Lausanne recently also, so any advice given here is reaching at least 3 or 4 people.
