Hi All, 
I have been checking this site regularly but this is my first post. I am in a trivial situation, in which I would want to know your opinions and suggestions. In Dec 2005, Even though I did not register to cablecom, I got a parcel from them and I accepted from the post office as I don't know where it come from. Soon, I sent them emails about this issue and told them to cancel this and let me know the address to which I have to send the kit. They sent me back mail to say that I have to send a written and signed letter to them (weird as I did no signature on any paper, but still got the kit...). So I did. They courteously told me that the cancellation is accepted but I have to pay for one year as the minimum contract is one year. I called them and tried to explain them and couldn't get a proper response. I was just getting bills but I didnt want to pay them, as I had never ever connected thru the cablecom network (Funnily, I had another internet from my apartment owner for the whole apartment ..which is thru the phone line). Also mine is a furnished apartment and I dont have a contract with my owner, as I knew him thru one of my friend. So I don't pay for the cable and is not in my name...    
Later cablecom passed on this issue to a debt collector agency, I still didn't know what to do.. Sent them mail asking for the copy of my signed contract, they never came back on that, And I sent back the cablecom kit to the person I was corresponding in Cablecom (As I didn't know the logistics department address). Even after doing all this, I had no solution and now I was getting my bills from the debt collector agency with all the added amount.   
Recently, I got a letter from the office de la pursuites. I sent back the letter saying I oppose to pay. I am sure this issue is getting bad to worse each time and I am not able to solve it. I just want to finish this issue. 
What can I do in this situation, what is the best step to take? I have a L permit and I also want to know if this would affect my extension of the permit.

Hi all,   
Thank you for the feedback so far... I finally bit the bullet and after several attempts and issues with Cablecom, I got the Digital box (I might start a separate thread on this but apparently our landlord does not have a contract with cablecom, so we could not get digital cable for ourselves!). So far (I got the box on Thursday) I have been quite disappointed with what is available in English language. Also it is very hard from the program guide to see whether or not a program will be available in English.    
I stumbled across The Simpsons on Friday afternoon, and despite the fact that the cable box indicated that the program was in English, Homer was still talking German.   Very annoying.   
There are also issues with the channels which are 'Dual' based where the option is not for a specific language, but for ORG (which I assume stands for Original) - since the cablebox does not automatically switch to that. National Geographic being one of those.   
I have to say that the only thing which I have been impressed with is the performance of the processor in the box. It seems like it is quite a beefy CPU. Compared to my HD-TIVO in the US this box is extremely fast.   
History Channel, Playhouse Disney and Toon Disney are not available in English - which seems ridiculous to me as they almost exclusively broadcast shows and documentaries which were originally in English and dubbed.   
I have written to Cablecom to complain, but I am sure the complaint will fall on deaf ears.   
Jose

As of April 2007 Cablecom is the cheapest alternative. You can buy a set top box for CHF 150 and receive 93 digital channels including BBC 1-2, ITV 1.-2, Film 4 , BBC World and BBC Prime. There are no additional costs other than the cable connection which is included in the rent. With Bluewin you need to have a telephone and Internet connection running up to CHF 63 a month. You can get some pretty good deals in the UK but the big drawback is that most of them are capped.   
   For example, I had BT broadband installed at my parents' place and it works out at 23 gbp per month (56 CHF) for 6 meg ADSL, with an included VoIP service that gives free evening and weekend UK calls with rates comparable to Skype for other calls.  I get 250 mins a month of time on their openzone system of WiFi hotspots as a freebie.  They also gave me a free wireless hub with the VoIP functionality when I joined.   Finally, BT have a really good Usenet news service provided by Giganews for which you'd normally pay about 10 dollars per month.   
  This compared to 80CHF per month that I was paying in Zuerich for cablecom 5 meg broadband (inc. the hire of the modem) with no extras.     
   That's a pretty good deal BUT the Broadband is limited to a pretty paltry 6 gigs of traffic per month before they start thinking about forcing you to move to a more expensive service or charging you per meg.   
  The Cablecom service was unlimited traffic (on one occasion I managed to use about 40 gigs in a month but 10-15 was typical) and I could have saved 15CHF per month by buying a cablemodem outright instead of renting it from Cablecom.     
   The thing about the UK though is that you have a huge choice of ADSL providers.  Plus many companies give you 'free' ADSL if you take up another of their services.  eg. 'Talk Talk' from Carphone Warehouse or Sky Broadband.  If you are prepared to do your homework, chances are that you can get a better deal that Switzerland but if you just want no-fuss broadband then the Swiss model might be better.     
Gav

Just be aware, there are more than one Astra satellite.    
The UK channels (Sky) are on the satellite Astra 2A which is at 28.2 degrees East.   
There is astra 1 which is the German channels which is at 19 degrees East and hotbird at 13 (German/ French and Middle East) degrees East.    
What I am saying is that if you point your dish at the UK channels ie Sky which has a number of subscription HDTV channels then you will not  
be able to pick up Astra one and hotbird via the same dish.

Has anyone else noticed these new offers from Sunrise? I must say at first glance they look quite interesting.   
As always the devil is in the detail, and these things have to be picked apart to see where the surprises are.   
We seem to have 4 offers to examine here, and all have in common the fact that for calls to Swiss land lines and other Sunrise phones that the calls are billed by the hour, rather than the minute.   
FINE PRINT: Calls of up to 5 seconds are billed at 5rp, but calls between 5-60sec are billed exactly the same as if they were over 60 seconds - in other words the flat rate. If you often make calls under 60 seconds then you will be worse off under this plan.   
Of course if you mostly call land lines and other sunrise mobiles then these offers are very interesting, especially if you love to talk for ages. Even if you call Swisscom mobiles these are billed by the second and the per minute rates.   
Anyway, onto the four plans:       
0.49/hour(or min), monthly charge: None       
0.59/hour(or min), monthly charge: None       
0.49/hour(or min), monthly charge: 15       
0.39/hour(or min), monthly charge: 25 
Bonus: Capped at 39 francs - FINE PRINT: *ONLY* for calls to fixnet and sunrise calls, and not counting the 25 francs. International calls and calls to other mobile numbers are not counted!   
Now is it just me or is there something strange here?    
For example, Just would would the advantage be to choosing libero over pronto? The rate is higher with libero and the monthly charge is the same. Or what about comparing pronto with basic - same rate but basic costs 15 francs more (compared to 0).    
So what gives? Are sunrise effectively charging the post paid people 15 francs per month more because they will get an itemised bill? Well that isn't unreasonable - with pre-pay there is no bill, so it is only fair that should work out cheaper - it's just that it never has been up to now!   
The way I see it - I'm going to switch to the pronto plan and go to pre-pay! Unless of course there are really great deals on new handsets that save me more than the cost of the contract over 12 months, but that's another story and I still have to check that part out.   
So now let's look at the "super" plan and compare it to pronto. You get 0.10 francs per hour(min) less but it costs you 25 francs per month   
So that means you'd have to make more than 250 hours or minutes in a month to make it more attractive. Another bonus is the cap at 39 francs, so actually you'd have to do more than 100 hours or minutes before it became worthwhile.   
In the old plan 100 minutes would be a border that a few people would cross. But what about if your calls to fixnet and sunrise are now measured in hours instead of minutes. Now all of a sudden we are looking at 100 *calls* per month, not minutes.    
That kind of changes things, and I doubt that many people would be ahead on the super plan.   
The exception of course is if your mobile bill involves a lot of international calls or long calls to swisscom mobiles, then it would merit more examination.   
But the way I see it - most existing sunrise consumers will find that the pre-pay pronto offer is best for them.   
Anyone else with any views on this? Did I miss anything?

I have Sunrise too but it has only happened to me a couple of times. Friends of mine that have Swisscom or Orange seem to have that problem a lot more often.   
At any rate, it's irritating and a damn nuisance. Even if it only happens now and then. And of course, if it happens to you a lot, then it just @#§° HELL!!!

Hi Gav,   
absolutely right... at least that is what the telephone companies want you to believe - that you are left with 13 months and 30 days but it is questionable legally. Point been that here there is a "fine" for terminating the contract before the minimum period is over and this part along with the legality of renewing a contract indefinitely in the way they do ie all terms apply as if the contract was newly signed(inc min period) was what we wanted to challenge but they did not want in the original above.   
Rgds   
Richard

....if you're intent on having a dish up for this then monoblock is an excellent solution.  If you're a bit of a hacker (and it seems you're NOT!  ) then you could dig into CAMs and the like; failing that, plug your address into the Cablecom page and you'll find out if they serve you and what services you can get:      - top-right IIRC switches to English   
As Richard said, their base-package is available with 50-60 channels of varying quality; for Premiership you might want to see about the digital offerings or Premier   
And Billag is available in French, German and Italian.  It did used to also be in English.  Call their hotline and you will be able to speak to someone who speaks English....0844 834 834.
